Earnings week in high gear, Estee Lauder and Ralph Lauren shares jumping this morning on better-than-expected earnings. Take a look, Estee Lauder up almost 10 percent right now, Polo Ralph Lauren up almost seven percent. Viacom had been lower. It has turned higher, it was a mixed report. We're breaking down all the earnings news this morning, and that is certainly moving markets.

Futures, meanwhile, expected to be up strongly up another 100 points at the start of trading, about a third of a percent. The S&P 500 is up five points right now, and the NASDAQ up 20 points also one-third of a percent higher on NASDAQ. In Europe, the markets are also higher across the board, FT-100 up 1-1/3 percent, 93 points higher. CAC Quarante in Paris up better than one percent as is the DAX Index in Germany, up 120 points there. Asian markets mostly closed overnight for the Lunar New Year, the Chinese New Year. Japan was down, however.

Countdown to the State of the Union back in the U.S., the President is calling for unity. He will say that tonight while he threatens to call for a national emergency to fund the border wall. The two sides digging in. A Mexican police meanwhile are beefing up their presence at the border this morning. These pictures just in, this is just happening right now. These police are in riot gear. They are waiting the arrival of the migrant caravan, which should get to the border shortly.

Meanwhile, there's this, breaking bread, Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell having dinner with President Trump last night at the White House on Jay Powell's birthday. Saddle up, I'm talking to the owner of a horse named, you guessed it, Maria Bartiromo. Hey, don't bet against Maria Bartiromo. We're going to take a look at that horse this morning.

But first, our top story this half an hour, the State of the Union, after a one week delay, President Trump is preparing to give his State of the Union Address tonight. He is expected to call for optimism and unity as another potential government shutdown looms. Joining me right now is RNC Chairwoman Ronna Romney McDaniel. Good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us, Ronna.

RONNA ROMNEY MCDANIEL, CHAIRWOMAN, RNC: Thanks for having me. Always good to be here.

BARTIROMO: So, what's your take? How is the President going to say, yes, we want unity and everything is great, the economy is doing well when we know we just came off of a government shutdown, 35 days the government was a closed. And the two sides are digging in, there's resist, resist, resist in the President's face all of the time.

MCDANIEL: Well, you're continuing to see the President put forward bipartisan compromise to Democrats, putting DACA on the table. Democrats said if the government opens, we'll work with you on good faith to find a compromise. We know there's an immigration crisis, the President did that. So, he's going to continue to keep that theme, and he's saying "choosing greatness" we need to put aside our political differences. The American people want to see us work together to solve real problems that are facing every American.

BARTIROMO: So, what's the plan to push back on this resist, Ronna? I mean, are you going to have two years of nothing getting done because everything the Republicans want to try to get accomplished is met with resistance, everything the President says is met with resistance? Do you have a plan to battle this?

MCDANIEL: Well, a lot of that is in the Democrats' hands. And we've seen this since President Trump was elected with the amount of Democrats that boycotted the inauguration. You're seeing Democrats boycotting the State of the Union tonight. This is really where their party has gone, resist and obstruct. Reject the results of the 2016 election because we didn't like what happened. That's a bad precedent for our country. We need to recognize the American people elected President Trump, and we need to do our best to help him be successful, and support our President.

The Democrats aren't doing that. So, from the Republican's side of things, we're going to continue offering the olive branch. We're going to say, come work with us, and I think the American people will decide, Republicans are getting things done, we're getting results, Democrats are continuing to double down on resistance.

BARTIROMO: I could -- I could count at least three or four Democrats who have already said, I'm not going. They said, we don't want to be there. So, they've already said they're not coming. And then, there's another movement to wear white in the face of another sort of way that they're going to push back on the President. Then, you've got all these special guests to be at the State of the Union tonight. The President has the 11-year-old boy named Joshua Trump coming. He's been bullied at school because of his last name. They're not even related. The Democrats are bringing furloughed federal workers, undocumented people who worked at Trump golf clubs. What about this, the undocumented people working at Trump golf clubs?

MCDANIEL: Well, I think the Democrats especially with the furloughed workers. I mean, they should say to those furloughed workers. Hey, guess what, the government is open because of the President. If we had our way, it would still be shut cause we're not going to compromise. So, I think it's ironic that they're bringing furloughed workers. Listen, the President's guest exemplify the results of this administration.

Matthew Charles, the first inmate let go, because of the First Step Act, reducing prison sentences for nonviolent crimes, letting people get back into society, what a great story. He has Alice Johnson, you have people from the Tree of Life Synagogue. You have a couple -- a family of a couple who was killed in Nevada last month by an illegal immigrant. So, the President's highlighting issue after issue and saying to Democrats we need to focus on policies that are going to help the American people, not partisan petty politics.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDANIEL: They are choosing pettiness, the President is choosing greatness, and he is inviting them along with him. Let's do great things for this country.

BARTIROMO: Well, you make a lot of good points. What about this fight that went on on Twitter? I mean, New York Freshman Congressman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez says she's bringing the activist who confronted Senator Jeff Flake. You remember this? That was over his vote on Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court. She's been a real star for Democrats. She's got nearly 3 million followers on Twitter, more than Nancy Pelosi, more than Chuck Schumer. Some are comparing her influence to President Trump's. So, what about the power of AOC, do you think she is the face of this party?

MCDANIEL: Well, she is certainly very powerful in the Democrat Party. And you're seeing her party move further and further left. Listen, AOC is a socialist. She is proposing government takeover of our education, of our health care. We're looking at Venezuela right now and the disaster that is, and she's just trying to take us step-by-step closer to a socialist nation. It is frightening what she's proposing. She has no backup as to how she would pay for those things except for taxing people at a 70 percent tax rate. That would be devastating to our country and our economy. But all the 2020 candidates are lobbying her because they're going to need her base and her enthusiasm to win, which is just going to show how out of step the Democrat Party is becoming from mainstream America that recognizes the greatness of our country, of Democracy, of capitalism, and the ability to achieve the American Dream.

BARTIROMO: Well, you know what's amazing, I mean, it's like we're speaking different languages because that's not the way Chuck Schumer sees it. You heard the sound bites earlier and Schumer -- Senator Schumer and Senator Sanders, Bernie Sanders, wrote an op-ed for the New York Times today, maybe you saw it, in support of limiting corporate stock buybacks. Democratic Presidential contenders for 2020 are also supporting this idea. They want to ban stock buybacks. Is this going to be an issue for the presidential campaign, and what does this say about big government? They're telling companies how to allocate their capital now.

MCDANIEL: If they could, they would regulate everything. And what they refuse to acknowledge, Maria, is jobs are coming back to this country. We saw 304,000 jobs last month, you have wages up over three percent, growing over three percent. The first time in a decade that you've seen that happen. You have 4 million people now off of food stamps under the Trump administration. Things are going great in this country, because of a couple things, deregulation, getting the government out of business, and the tax cuts, making our corporate tax cuts -- corporate tax rates competitive, and giving people more money to invest in our economy. It is working, and Democrats can't even acknowledge that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Real quick, Ronna, what would be victory --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDANIEL: -- is the answer.

BARTIROMO: What would be victory tonight for the President? What does he need to do to come away from this strong?

MCDANIEL: Well, I think the President is talking to the American people. And they're going to see this is a President who's putting forward reasonable, sound solutions, and Democrats continue to reject it. I don't have hope that the Democrats are going to come across the aisle and work with this President because they haven't since day one.

BARTIROMO: So, national emergency. You think he'll declare national emergency then for the border?

MCDANIEL: I don't know. I think the President is doing the right thing, trying to take every possible step to work with Congress. But listen, we do have a crisis at our border. You just showed pictures of this caravan about to come across. We know 90 percent of the heroin is coming across our southern border. 300 deaths from heroin a week. Human trafficking is an issue. We just saw the MS-13 shooting last night in New York City. This is a problem that we need to address, 2,000 people are trying to cross our border illegally. Every single day, it's only getting worse, and it's been three decades of getting nothing done in Washington. And this is a President that doesn't settle and say OK, let's just get nothing done. He's here to get things done.

BARTIROMO: It's a very scary sight what we're looking at right now, Ronna, you're right. These are live pictures from Negras, Mexico, where the Mexico police are in riot gear. They are lined up at the border waiting for this caravan to come. So, it looks like Mexico is assisting the United States at this point in this.

And you mentioned the MS-13 shooting, that's on the cover of the New York Post today, MS-13 on the train. That was the southern train broad daylight shooting, and it was a gang fight. Really scary stuff, Ronna, and this is -- this is the post this morning, by the way, everybody. Ronna Romney McDaniel, thank you so much for weighing in this morning. We will see you soon.

MCDANIEL: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it very much. Be sure to stay with Fox Business tonight. We've got live coverage of the President's State of the Union Address. It kicks off at 7:00 p.m. Eastern, and then MORNINGS WITH MARIA will be live tomorrow morning in Washington, D.C. Join me for the highlights from the speech. I'll also be sitting down with a "FIRST ON FOX EXCLUSIVE" with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. That's tomorrow at 7:00 a.m. Eastern right here. Join us for that special interview.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, Alphabet reporting earnings last night after the bell. The stock is down two percent. It is off of the lows despite a double beat on earnings and revenue. Stuart Varney weighs in on that when we come back. And then, focus on the Fed, what is in store for the Central Bank following Fed Chief Jay Powell's dinner last night with President Trump. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Alphabet reporting fourth-quarter earnings last night, slowing revenue growth, shrinking margins concerning investors. Stock is down. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney, to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It wasn't that bad.

BARTIROMO: No.

VARNEY: It just wasn't that bad. I'm not buying this. What is the stock down about $24.00 -- down 22 bucks, about two percent down. I'm not buying that. I think that Alice is saying it's down because Google, Alphabet is spending money on hiring new people and data centers. OK, I got that. Are they ignoring the 2 billion monthly users on YouTube which has yet to be monetized. They seem to be ignoring that. I just don't get it, Maria. I'm not going to say the analysts are wrong, the market is wrong, I just don't get this particular equation. And if I was left to guess, I'd say that Google bounces back fairly quickly to not necessarily its old high which is 12 percent high than where it is now, but certainly bounces back from this downturn that it's going to take first thing this morning. What do you think? What do you think?

BARTIROMO: Well, it was a big number in terms of what they're spending. You know how they have all of these other businesses that they want to --

VARNEY: Sure.

BARTIROMO: -- that they want to diversify. But 90 percent of the business is still, what, search and advertising, right?

VARNEY: Isn't this what they're supposed to do? I mean, aren't you supposed to plow back your profits in to expansion, new businesses, and (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: That's true, yes. You would think analysts like that.

VARNEY: Yes, you would have thought. But this time, no. I'm sorry, I don't get it. But I'm not nasty about analysts or that or expectations. I just don't get it.

BARTIROMO: All right. Well, I know you'll have more on it. And plus, you're going to preview Disney. That's after the close tonight.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in about 10 minutes, Stu. Thanks so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

But first, the economy under President Trump. The President dining with Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell last night at the White House. It was Powell's birthday. Then saddle up, I'm speaking with the owner of one special horse named, you guessed it, Maria Bartiromo. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: We are less than an hour away from the opening bell this morning. We are expecting a gain at the start of trading about 100 points. Investors are watching earnings. But what also is important is what President Trump will say at tonight's State of the Union Address.

Joining us right now is Wayne Wicker, he is Vantage Point Investment Advisors' Chief Investment Officer. Wayne, it's good to see you this morning. Does the State of the Union matter to investors? What do you want to see in order to move markets tomorrow -- tonight?

WAYNE WICKER, CIO, VANTAGE POINT INVESTMENT ADVISORS: Maria, I think that this is the perfect time for President Trump to come out and talk to the nation. He's really standing on solid footing economically. You've seen jobless claims coming in really strong, you see these earnings are coming in well. I think that investors are really going to be focused on a level of optimism going forward in his words this evening, to propel markets higher.

BELL: Wayne, Lindsey Bell here. What's your read on the meeting last night, the dinner last night between Jerome Powell and President Trump and Steve Mnuchin and Richard Clarida? What do you think markets should take from that? Do you think that, you know, the Fed still remains independent. What's the underlying thing to read?

WICKER: Well, Lindsey, I think that we saw the big pivot at the beginning of this year, when we moved away from auto escalation to more of a data dependency. I think what we saw last night was a little bit more of the same thing, where the Fed is trying to be -- quite frankly, a little bit more benign in their approach, and I think the combination of what Fed Powell is talking about as well as some of these meetings that he had with the administration, solidified that in investors' minds these days.

BELL: What are you pricing in for rate hikes this year?

WICKER: Well, I would say that the market probably has it right, that you don't see any inflation right now, and it's modest growth in the United States, and really not that great a growth outside the United States. So, the market is suggesting maybe one hike later on this year. I don't disagree with that.

BARTIROMO: So, you would buy stocks here?

WICKER: I would absolutely buy stocks in this market. You've seen some really strong earnings growths for the first half of earnings reporting season here. I see that despite the fact that we had this V-shaped recovery which history would say, you may have some retracement at some point in the next few months. I think the longer-term outlook is very strong for equities today.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Wayne, great to have you weigh in. Thank you.

WICKER: Uh-huh.

BARTIROMO: Wayne Wicker joining us there. Up next, the owner of Maria Bartiromo, the horse. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, a winning combination, champions are crowned at Rodeo Rapid City in South Dakota this past weekend. One horse went 87 points for saddle bronc riding, and the name of that horse -- Maria Bartiromo. Joining us right now by the telephone is the owner of Maria Bartiromo the horse, Matt Burch. Matt, thank you so much for being here.

MATT BURCH, OWNER OF MARIA BARTIROMO THE HORSE (via telephone): Thank you for having us.

BARTIROMO: Why did you name your horse Maria Bartiromo?

BURCH: Well, my dad is the one that started this. We're big time Fox News watchers. And he was sitting there one day and he normally writes horses' names down on paper that he wants us to name, me and my brother, and he told us that he wanted us to find one horse and wanted to name it after you because you're an intelligent person, very classy, so he told us to make sure we picked it on a good one, so that age of colts we start them at 5 years old. And for about four or five trips, we could tell that this mare right here was the most talented, classy, intelligent one of the bunch.

MCDOWELL: Hey, Matt --

BURCH: And obviously, you can see she's very pretty. So, I think (INAUDIBLE) you know, big white mane on her.

BARTIROMO: She's gorgeous.

MCDOWELL: I have to (INAUDIBLE)

BURCH: After about five trips, my brother said there's our horse. So, we put your name on it and come to find out, she is our number one horse of that colt crop, and probably one of the best ones we're hauling down the road right now.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

MCDOWELL: Hey, Matt, did your daddy know that there was actually another horse, a racehorse that was also named after Maria Bartiromo at one point?

BURCH: Well, I've seen that before, yes. And I'm sure my dad did -- probably had seen that before, but you know, from the racehorse business to where we go is the (INAUDIBLE) horse deal, two totally different kind of horses. So, my dad is a very intelligent man, I'm sure he probably knew that.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I love -- I am so honored and she performed how often, Maria Bartiromo? Yes.

BURCH: Oh, that mare, well, she'll go about 20 trips all-year long. She goes to all of the biggest rodeos we go to. She's been to Houston, Texas, Clovis, California, (INAUDIBLE) Idaho, San Antonio, Texas, Denver, Colorado, Rapid City, obviously. Las Vegas, Nevada, to the (INAUDIBLE) NFR.

BARTIROMO: That is great. Listen, we're going to keep checking on her. We so appreciate it. And I appreciate it. I'm so honored, Matt, thank you very much. All the best to you and your father.

BURCH: Well, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Matt Burch --

BURCH: OK. (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: -- joining us.

MCDOWELL: We got to get you to a Rodeo. We got to go to the NFR in December. That is rad.

BARTIROMO: Let's do that. All right. Have a great day, everybody. Stuart Varney, take it away with "VARNEY & COMPANY."

END

You have 4 million people now off of food stamps under the Trump administration. Things are going great in this country, because of a couple things, deregulation, getting the government out of business, ...

<xhtml:span id="h1" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... up 83 points, better than 1 percent higher on Nasdaq . <xhtml:span class="hit">Big tech</xhtml:span> did well. Global markets this morning mostly higher. Take a look ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... to allocate their capital now. MCDANIEL: If they could, they would <xhtml:span class="hit">regulate</xhtml:span> everything. And what they refuse to acknowledge, Maria, is jobs are ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h3" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... Democrats move to Florida and then vote in tax policies and <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> policies that they fled here in the northeast which is a ...</xhtml:span>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VCB-D7K1-JBHT-D489-00000-00Super Bowl Ratings Sink; Trump to Pick World Bank Critic to Lead the Lender; Trump Committee Subpoenaed; Senate Votes to Oppose U.S. Troop Withdrawal in Syria and Afghanistan; ESPN Fires Popular Anchor; Crypto Exchange May Have Lost $137 Million; President Trump's State of The Union Address Takes Place Tonight2019-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:29ZLexisNexisSuper Bowl Ratings Sink; Trump to Pick World Bank Critic to Lead the Lender; Trump Committee Subpoenaed; Senate Votes to Oppose U.S. Troop Withdrawal in Syria and Afghanistan; ESPN Fires Popular Anchor; Crypto Exchange May Have Lost $137 Million; President Trump's State of The Union Address Takes Place TonightLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies. Good morning to you. Happy Tuesday, everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, February 5th. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Alphabet stock under pressure this morning, the parent company of Google, reporting strong fourth quarter results, but it was the expense side of the business, spending concerns dragging on the stock this morning. We're taking a closer look at that. Plus the other companies on tap including Disney today. Earnings round-up coming up.

Breaking bread, Federal Reserve Chairman, Jay Powell, having dinner with President Trump at the White House last night on Jay Powell's birthday. The details coming up right here. Countdown to State of the Union, President Trump set to tout his economic success tonight. We're taking a closer look at who will be attending as guests of the President and the Democrats.

Patriots on parade. The team celebrating its Super Bowl win in Boston this morning, following not-so super ratings for the big game. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

And we kick it off with markets right now. Take a look at futures indicating a gain at the start of trading this morning. Dow industrials right now up better than 70 points, a quarter of a percent higher, S&P 500 up 3-1/2, and the NASDAQ right now looking like it gained at the start of trading of about 11 points, this after the market started the week on a strong note. Big cap technology and industrial stocks led big a rally yesterday, take a look, the Dow industrials up 175 points at the close yesterday, up three quarters of a percent. The S&P was up 18 and the NASDAQ, with all those tech names there, up better than one percent, 84 points higher at the close yesterday.

Earnings season rolling on this morning with Google parent company, Alphabet, reporting after the bell last night. The numbers were better than expected last night, but the concerns are really over higher expenses and that's weighing on investors this morning. Company is spending more money on a whole host of businesses away from search. The stock down 2-1/2 right now this morning. Viacom, Walt Disney, and Snap all reporting today.

And joining me right now is Wells Fargo Asset Management Senior Investment Strategist, Brian Jacobsen. Brian, it's good to see you this morning.

BRIAN JACOBSEN, SENIOR INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for being here. So characterize, assess for us the fourth-quarter earnings period so far from your standpoint.

JACOBSEN: Sure. From our standpoint, it looks like the real story here isn't that it's a lot better than people expected, it's just that it could have been a lot worse. I think that with the December drubbing that we had with the equity markets, a lot of it was around rising risks of recession. But now those risks appear to be receding as we that about anywhere from 70 to 75 percent of companies that have reported have actually beat estimates depending upon, you know, which data provider you look at to get earnings estimates.

So, so far so good. And our expectation is that we're going to continue to see this economic expansion continue. And so we're continuing to favor more cyclical areas of the market, you know, the run-up with industrials and technology, to us isn't really all that surprising mainly because we thought that the market was overplaying the risks of recession.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a good point, because the risk of recession seems to be -- the commentary is getting louder and louder. But we know from a fundamental basis we saw earnings up better than 20 percent in 2018, 22 percent or something, and we're expecting earnings to be up, what, four percent, six percent.

JACOBSEN: They're --

BARTIROMO: So does that concern you that we're going to see such a slowdown and profitability?

JACOBSEN: Well, that doesn't happen all that often, but there is something somewhat unique about last year's numbers, is the fact that you did have tax cut, which probably contributed, you know, somewhere between anywhere from 10 to 11 percentage points to EPS growth.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

JACOBSEN: So part of it was a one-off with tax cuts. But we don't think that now we're going to see a rolling over of earnings. So, what I like to do when you do have these one-off effects like with tax cuts is really look at topline earnings growth as more of an indicator of the underlying strength of businesses, and there, that's still looking pretty healthy, about eight percent year-on-year expectations for the 12 months is something closer to around maybe fix to six percent, which is still pretty good, so it's nothing close to some people are talking about an earnings recession, where you have corporate profits falling, but the economy's still kind of trudging along. We don't think we're going to see that.

BARTIROMO: All right. The Fed, that's certainly one of the big stories for this market, a real pivot at the end of last year where the Fed told us at the beginning of this year as well, "Look, we are going to wait, we're going to -- it's going to be data-dependent, they may very well not raise at all this year and maybe we're even going to see them pullback on the balance sheet. Fed Chairman Powell dined with the President last night. Does that concern you? I mean in terms of the Fed's independence given the President's stance on the Fed for so long now?

JACOBSEN: It doesn't, and it's mainly because I think that the data justifies the pivot by the Fed. One of our big concerns going into the last part of 2018 was that the Federal Reserve was going to hike because they could, not because they should. There was, to us clear, evidence that the housing market had been suffering for a lot of 2018, that you had a lot of somewhat tightening of financial conditions and so I think that without the clear and present danger of inflation picking up, there's really no reason for the Fed to continue hiking as it was, so they're probably closer to being done than they are more towards the mid part of the game as far as with rate hikes. So, it wasn't really too surprising that they made the pivot, but the markets sure did cheer that on.

BARTIROMO: Does the State of the Union matter to investors? Is there anything that you would anticipate is said tonight at the State of the Union that could move markets tomorrow?

JACOBSEN: Well, I think that there are a few things that we could see, you know, if there's any sort of policy statement about, you know, let's say anything with drug pricing, or with -- the opioid epidemic.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. Good point, yes.

JACOBSEN: But otherwise, I think that we're going to be really looking for any teasers about trade policy. It seems like the talks have gone well so far and President Trump and President Xi are going to be meeting at the end of February so is he going to outline what some of those agreements are that they've come to? But then otherwise, probably going to focus on immigration and the border wall, which, from an investor perspective, probably isn't as meaningful except if it leads to further government shutdowns in the context of a debt ceiling debate.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

JACOBSEN: I think the most recent shutdown didn't really impact the markets much because it was partial, and also we weren't dealing with trying to raise the debt ceiling. Future ones, we may not be so lucky.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's great point. And real quick before you go, Disney and Viacom, any thoughts on those earnings today?

JACOBSEN: I don't have any really view on those --

BARTIROMO: OK.

JACOBSEN: I don't cover those. Those are up to our analysts.

BARTIROMO: Brian, it's great to see you.

JACOBSEN: Great to see you. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

JACOBSEN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it. Brian Jacobsen, great insights from you as always from Wells Fargo. Meanwhile, the Patriots' victory parade is this morning. You know it was the lowest-scoring Super Bowl in history. Also generating the game's lowest T.V. ratings in a decade. Dagen McDowell, good morning to you. What's your take here?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Well, lame commercials, Maroon, as this -- the half-time performers, and then a game about as interesting as watching your gran papi mow the lawn, that is why this Super Bowl was a ratings loser. 98.2 million people watched the Patriots beat the Rams, that is the smallest television audience since 2008 when the Giants beat the Patriots, we all remember that around New York City, that was a five percent drop in the ratings from last year, a 12 percent drop om ratings from the Super Bowl in 2017. Now 2.6 million people did stream the game across digital platforms. That is a digital record for viewership. It pushed the total audience above that 100 million mark, but this game needed it because people watching on T.V., a lot of them didn't show up, particular Los Angeles.

The ratings were weak for the Rams and down in New Orleans, the folks down there, the Saints fans upset, about that blown call that if they had gotten it right would have sent the Saints to the Super Bowl. That city had the lowest ratings for New Orleans in Super Bowl history. However, this Super Bowl and the rating, the poor ratings, cap a year where ratings have come back for the sport.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Before Sunday's game, ratings were up nine percent during the playoffs, five percent during regular season. It was people like Patrick Mahomes, people were --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- tuning in to watch him play, and Roger Goodell having a lower profile this past --

BARTIROMO: You're right. That's what I was going to say, Dagen, because I feel like over the last several months, the hoopla and the upset of the kneeling issue and concussions sort of went down. And I thought, "Well, maybe this is, you know, viewed are coming back." Not so.

MCDOWELL: The -- well, the --

BARTIROMO: Your numbers won't show it.

MCDOWELL: They were during the season, but again when you put up a game that was this awful to watch --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- where both -- neither offense really showed up. You can argue that it was all about the defense, no, it was just boring and people, well, went and did other things like, I don't know, groom their cats.

BARTIROMO: Oh God, you're tough. Thank you, Dagen. We'll see you in a few minutes. Meanwhile, President Trump is expected to announce some key nominations today. Lauren Simonetti with headlines now. Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. The President is expected to nominate Treasury Department Official, David Malpass, to be next leader of the World Bank. He is one of the World Bank's sharpest critics within the TRUMP ADMINISTRATION. Now the U.S. holds a controlling share of the bank's board voting power. And the President plans to nominate Former Energy Lobbyist, David Bernhardt, as Secretary of the Interior. Democrats and environmental groups have criticized that decision saying he is vulnerable to conflicts of interest.

President Trump's Inaugural Committee says it will comply with the subpoena from Federal Prosecutors. According to the Wall Street Journal, the Feds requesting documents related to spending and donations as well as information about benefits donors received from making contributions including tickets and photo opportunities with the President. Prosecutors also want documents related to donations made by foreign nationals. The committee raised a record-breaking $107 million, that leading up to the 2017 inauguration.

Amazon has named another African American to its mainly white board. Rosalind Brewer will become the second black female director for Amazon. She is Starbucks' Chief Operating Officer. The move comes as companies come under pressure to diversify their corporate boardrooms. Shares of Amazon are lower just fractionally in premarket trading at 16.33 a share, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren. Thank you. Coming up, the State of the Union is tonight. President Trump will deliver the speech after postponing it a week due to the shutdown. The key issues he hopes to tackle, plus his special guests right after this. And then crypto secret, nearly $200 million in cryptocurrency cannot be accessed because the only person with the password is no longer alive. He passed away. The stunning story coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We got a big program this morning. Coming up, California Congressman, House Minority Leader, Kevin McCarthy, here in the studio. Pennsylvania Congressman, and House Foreign Affairs Committee member, Scott Perry, here as well. RNC Chairwoman, Ronna Romney McDaniel, joining me along with FOX News Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane, here. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big three hours coming up.

We are also counting down to the State of the Union tonight. President Trump is set to address the country, highlighting some key issues that Americans face. Plus touting his economic success so far under his leadership. Joining the conversation this morning is 32 Advisors CEO, Former Economic Advisor to President Obama, Robert Wolf here. Along with CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, great to see you guys this morning.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So what should the President tackle tonight, Robert?

ROBERT WOLF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I agree. He should focus on the economy, which has been incredibly strong.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

WOLF: You know, he's going to have to go there on the combination of immigration, government shutdown, and talk about the deal he wants. My guess is half will stand, half will sit down. And I think he is going to have to talk about foreign policy because it seems like there's republicans that's starting not to basically agree with where he is on Syria. So, I think it's going to be a very interesting, you know, State of the Union. I know it's a week later than we were expecting, but I think it's always important to hear the President.

BELL: I think the timing of this is really good, too. After the government shutdown, this is a chance for President Trump to potentially regain some momentum, especially after the loss he incurred during that and really lay out the plan, like you said, with regards to immigration policy going forward.

BARTIROMO: Now we are expecting a slowdown. Is that largely because of the rest of the world, do you think? Is it because this expansion is going on 10 years, or is it something domestically in the U.S.? I mean I know housing has been a weak spot.

BELL: Yes. I mean I think of course the rest of the world is slowing down. And when China and Europe are slowing down, that is going to have an impact on our economy. But also we're cycling the sugar high of tax reform, fiscal policy, deregulation, so it's hard to comp on top of those numbers.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. OK. Tough comparisons.

WOLF: Yes, it is. We're -- we went off an incurably low base a decade ago, and now all of a sudden it's off a higher base and we're starting to see hourly earnings get better, wages get better, GDP get better, but the question is are we on the backend of that 10-year recovery, and it -- you know, listen, we have 50 percent of the economists saying so, but we have seen 50 percent of them be wrong many, many times.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: President Trump needs to talk about his strategy to keep this economy going and maybe get out of the way of it because, again, some of the administration's policies have put a damper on American business, the steel and aluminum tariffs that are still in place, and the exemptions weren't even getting processed during the government shutdown. He needs to lay out a two-year agenda on how he's going to keep the economy growing at a three percent rate.

By the way last year three percent plus rate, even though we haven't gotten the final, final numbers for the year, but that's the fastest since 2005. He has to continue that because voters have very short-term memories if he wants to get reelected.

BARTIROMO: How is he going to do that? I mean are there --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- areas in terms of policy that there's common ground or are we going to see the next two years resist, resist, resist? There are some Democrats who have already said, "I'm not going." Meaning he's over here. The President is also expected to make a call for unity tonight. Unity.

WOLF: Yes.

BARTIROMO: OK? Amid these massive divisions between the Republicans and the Democrats.

WOLF: Yes. The -- listen, the environment is more polarizing than it's ever been, you know. Since the midterms, there's no question that the Democratic Party has had a shift to the left. The biggest voices are more populist, whether it's Cortez or Priestley, or -- and there's a big push to the left. On the flip side, those who won in the Republican Party definitely a much more of the more conservative far-right base, so we've lost the center and we -- it would be great for all of us if we got the center back.

BARTIROMO: So what do you think about Howard Schultz? Is he the answer?

WOLF: You know, Howard Schultz, for me, is not the answer. I mean I like some of his policies, and if -- I wish he ran as a Democrat. I'm not one who's touring for an independent third party. I don't think it's where the country is right now.

BARTIROMO: So you think that he will take votes from the Dems?

WOLF: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLF: I think his -- he literally aligns with the Democrats 95 percent of the way.

BARTIROMO: Yes, he does.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I think that's a real problem for the Democrats going forward into 2020 and I think that the polarization of the country really is going to get people out there and voting this time around, too, I think.

BELL: Yes, but --

BARTIROMO: But shouldn't the Dems just recognize that? If much of the country is in the center like you are leaning to the left or leaning to the right, why can't the Democrats understand that and not have the loudest people in the room, those who want Medicare-for-all, abolish ICE, 70 percent tax rates like AOC?

WOLF: I think what's fascinating is if actually you looked at the midterms, the Democrats did best in the moderate areas. And if you look at most recent polling, actually the Democratic Party wants over 50 percent actually shift to the center, but it doesn't really make a difference what polling says.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

WOLF: The excitement and the electricity in the party is shifted to the left. That's where -- that's why I've always said the likely candidate for the Democratic Party who could win a primary will have a tougher time in the national election.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. Good point. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Let's call -- let's talk about unity, though. The Criminal Justice Reform, signed into law by President Trump, it had bipartisan support. One of the guests at the State of the Union from the President tonight will be Matthew Charles, the first man released from prison under this. I think that he's also going to have Alice Johnson there whose sentence was commuted by President Trump. This is something that the Democrats should be cheering more loudly than they are right now.

BARTIROMO: But because it's President Trump they're not.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That's the whole thing.

BARTIROMO: That's -- I think people are going to get frustrated with all of this constant resist. I mean, are the women going to wear all white?

WOLF: I don't know what they're wearing.

BARTIROMO: More games. Why can't we just work together?

MCDOWELL: I --

BARTIROMO: It's just --

MCDOWELL: I am most interested to watch the face of Nancy Pelosi --

BARTIROMO: Behind President Trump, yes.

MCDOWELL: -- this entire State of the Union.

BARTIROMO: Yes, me, too.

MCDOWELL: I hope she rehearses stoicism.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: So -- because, again, it's going to be --

BELL: It's the sign of that resist.

MCDOWELL: That's going to be -- that's going to be the thing that we're all talking about.

BARTIROMO: Well, you're going to watch it right here as FOX Business --

MCDOWELL: Yes, absolutely.

BARTIROMO: -- is going to have live coverage of President Trump's State of the Union tonight. It all kicks off at 7:00 p.m. Eastern. The President will speak at 9:00 p.m. and we'll be watching both Nancy Pelosi and Vice President Pence behind the President and, of course, focused on the President's speech. MORNINGS WITH MARIA will be live tomorrow morning from Washington, D.C. with the highlights from the speech and a whole host of terrific guests.

I'll be sitting down with Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, tomorrow, at 7:00 a.m. Eastern. Join us for this exclusive tomorrow morning from Washington with the Secretary of State right here. Coming up first, the war on terror, we're talking about it next. The Pentagon is warning about the future of ISIS in Syria as the senate votes to keep troops there on the ground defying President Trump. The debate coming up. Then Hawaii may say aloha to smoking. The interesting way the state wants to phase out the sale of cigarettes next up right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. . Headlines across America this morning. The Hawaii Tribune-Herald writing a Local Representative Richard Creagan is proposing a cigarette ban. The bill is aimed at stopping the sale of cigarettes by increasing the minimum age to buy them --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- to 100 years. The age would be slowly increased over several years starting at 30 years old in 2020, 40 in 2021, and then 100 by 2024. Over to the Chicago Tribune, it's reporting today is O'Hare is once again the nation's busiest airport in terms of total flights. O'Hare International reclaimed the titled from Atlanta for the first time since 2014. In total, there were over 900,000 thousand flights in and out of O'Hare just last year. Finally from The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia is considering banning cashless stores. Philly City Council will consider a bill today that would prevent stores from refusing to accept cash and prevent stores from charging people more if they pay with cash.

Interesting stories here in the headlines across America. What do you think that's all about in Philly? I mean I'm wondering if facial recognition is -- people are looking at it and giving it second thoughts.

WOLF: I don't like the idea of cashless stores because I think people don't really use their credit cards that well, right? And they don't realize they're paying 18, 20 percent.

BARTIROMO: That's true, yes.

WOLF: So I think actually, you know, everyone thinks it's for free until they start getting their invoices.

BARTIROMO: You don't know how much you're spending.

WOLF: So, I'm a little nervous about that.

BELL: Yes, but I feel like it's the way that technology is taking us. I mean you have on your iPhone Apple Pay and all these things, people are using Venmo more and more often. I just feel like it's the way the world --

WOLF: But people -- but the other side is you're giving more of your information when people want to start going the other way.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: That's fair. That's fair.

WOLF: I mean -- I mean the whole privacy thing -- great, we're going to have 10 more apps on our phone that has everything we do every step of the way. I don't --

MCDOWELL: But there are some small businesses that don't want to accept cash. All you need is a Square account and the Square app and you just a do swipe. You even use your -- even use your mobile device --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- to ring up customers. So why force small business owners to accept cash?

BARTIROMO: Well --

MCDOWELL: People have the right to not shop there. It's not a -- it -- we're not talking about supermarkets and drugstores, I doubt.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. By the way, you mentioned, you know, the data, that's why China is number one in A.I. because of all of the data that it has collected about people.

WOLF: Yes. I mean we were talking offset. I think one of the most important things that the President's going to say tonight is where he is with China. What's important is the tariff and trade, where is it with intellectual property. On the flip side, he knows he wants to put an olive branch out there because March 1st is kind of the deadline before tariffs go up.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLF: So he's got to figure out how he wants to thread the needle between hitting them publicly, but also not hitting them too hard during the negotiation. It will be interesting what he does, but obviously intellectual property is the big elephant in the room.

BARTIROMO: It is.

WOLF: It's not about steel and trade and tariffs.

BARTIROMO: I want to get into this because if they do a deal that just allows China to buy more stuff -- yesterday, China said that it is poised to buy more soybean and grain, and then leave I.P. and the forced transfer if technology on the cutting room floor, big trouble. Big -- that is a big issue and we'll talk about it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I'm still asking the question why are the steel and aluminum tariffs still in place if you've gotten the deal with Mexico and Canada and you're on the road to doing something about China, why are they still there. And stop talking about them as a revenue generator.

BARTIROMO: Let me -- let me just say, because I've asked this question of the administration and they will say if we don't have steel and aluminum tariffs all over, China will find the opening, and they will push through steel through Canada or somewhere else, that's what the administration will say. We had to do it everywhere including our friends because otherwise there will be open pockets where China will push their product.

MCDOWELL: And they're wildly overselling that threat.

WOLF: Yes, I would respectfully --

MCDOWELL: Wildly overselling that threat.

BELL: Yes.

WOLF: I would respectfully disagree.

BELL: And it's -- and it's --

BARTIROMO: OK.

WOLF: Make sure I'm being respectful. Respectful disagree.

MCDOWELL: And it's the putting the screws to American manufacturers and costing people jobs.

BARTIROMO: Big impact. Big impact. All right. Quick break, and then staying in Iraq, that is the question. President Trump outlines the plan to keep eye on Iran from Iraq, but politicians there are pushing back. We've got the details coming up. And then it's World Nutella Day, yes, it is. How you can score some free jars with your name on it, this and more right after this, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning, welcome back, everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, February 5th, your top stories right now, 6:31 a.m. on the East Coast.

Big names reporting earnings today, Viacom will be out in about half an hour, investors are also keeping an eye on Disney and Snap, reporting later today.

Meanwhile, investors are looking to extend a winning streak this morning, Futures indicating another start that is strong this morning, Dow industrials up better than 90 points right now, about a third of a percent, the S&P 500 is up s6, a quarter of a percent, and the NASDAQ up 18.

Even though we are seeing some weakness in companies like Alphabet, after its earnings last night, the major indices finished at the highest close in two months yesterday. Take a look at yesterday's close, with the Dow Industrials picked up 175 points, 3 quarters of 1 percent, the S&P 500 was up 18, that was two-thirds of a percent, and the NASDAQ with 83-point rally yesterday, up better than 1 percent.

I mentioned Alphabet, it is down, even though the numbers were better-than-expected, the company is seeing higher expenses, we'll talk about it coming up.

European indices this morning, look like this, and they are higher across the board, FT 100 up 1-1/2 percent right now, 106 points higher in London, CAC Quarante in Paris is up better than 1 percent, 54 points higher, and the DAX Index in Germany, up 142 points, one and a quarter percent higher this morning, big winners in Europe, today.

In Asia overnight, the indices are, well, largely closed for the lunar holiday, it is the Chinese New Year. Japan was down by just a fraction.

We are on the countdown to tonight's State of the Union Address, with the guest list expanding on all sides. President Trump is expected to call for unity in tonight's address.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Most importantly, in the State of the Union, the President is calling for an end to, sort of, resistance in retribution politics and calling for cooperation and compromise.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: FOX Business will have special coverage of the State of the Union tonight. We all start it off at 7:00 p.m. Eastern tonight, with Lou Dobbs. MORNINGS WITH MARIA will be live tomorrow morning in Washington with special guests.

I will be speaking with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo tomorrow morning, join us for that special interview, as we take a look at the President's foreign policy with the Secretary of State tomorrow, live from Washington.

Plus this, crypto mistake, Canada's largest exchange locked out of more than $130 million worth of crypto currency, because the only person who can access it has died. He's the only person that had the password, we will tell you about that. Then, spreading joy, it is World Nutella Day, and we will tell you how you can score your own Nutella, free jar with your name on it, all coming up this morning.

But first, our top story this half an hour, troop withdrawal backlash, the Senate has voted to oppose President Trump's troop withdrawal in Syria and Afghanistan. And the measure says that ISIS is still posing a serious threat. And if the U.S. leaves, it opens the door for Russia and Iran to gain power in the region.

Joining me right now is Retired Four-Star General and FOX News Senior Strategic Analyst General Jack Keane, General, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

MCDANIEL: Well, I think the President is talking to the American people. And they're going to see this is a President who's putting forward reasonable, sound solutions, and Democrats continue to reject it. I don't have hope that the Democrats are going to come across the aisle and work with this President because they haven't since day one.

BARTIROMO: So, national emergency. You think he'll declare national emergency then for the border?

MCDANIEL: I don't know. I think the President is doing the right thing, trying to take every possible step to work with Congress. But listen, we do have a crisis at our border. You just showed pictures of this caravan about to come across. We know 90 percent of the heroin is coming across our southern border. 300 deaths from heroin a week. Human trafficking is an issue. We just saw the MS-13 shooting last night in New York City. This is a problem that we need to address, 2,000 people are trying to cross our border illegally. Every single day, it's only getting worse, and it's been three decades of getting nothing done in Washington. And this is a President that doesn't settle and say OK, let's just get nothing done. He's here to get things done.

BARTIROMO: It's a very scary sight what we're looking at right now, Ronna, you're right. These are live pictures from Negras, Mexico, where the Mexico police are in riot gear. They are lined up at the border waiting for this caravan to come. So, it looks like Mexico is assisting the United States at this point in this.

And you mentioned the MS-13 shooting, that's on the cover of the New York Post today, MS-13 on the train. That was the southern train broad daylight shooting, and it was a gang fight. Really scary stuff, Ronna, and this is -- this is the post this morning, by the way, everybody. Ronna Romney McDaniel, thank you so much for weighing in this morning. We will see you soon.

MCDANIEL: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it very much. Be sure to stay with Fox Business tonight. We've got live coverage of the President's State of the Union Address. It kicks off at 7:00 p.m. Eastern, and then MORNINGS WITH MARIA will be live tomorrow morning in Washington, D.C. Join me for the highlights from the speech. I'll also be sitting down with a "FIRST ON FOX EXCLUSIVE" with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. That's tomorrow at 7:00 a.m. Eastern right here. Join us for that special interview.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, Alphabet reporting earnings last night after the bell. The stock is down two percent. It is off of the lows despite a double beat on earnings and revenue. Stuart Varney weighs in on that when we come back. And then, focus on the Fed, what is in store for the Central Bank following Fed Chief Jay Powell's dinner last night with President Trump. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Alphabet reporting fourth-quarter earnings last night, slowing revenue growth, shrinking margins concerning investors. Stock is down. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney, to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It wasn't that bad.

BARTIROMO: No.

VARNEY: It just wasn't that bad. I'm not buying this. What is the stock down about $24.00 -- down 22 bucks, about two percent down. I'm not buying that. I think that Alice is saying it's down because Google, Alphabet is spending money on hiring new people and data centers. OK, I got that. Are they ignoring the 2 billion monthly users on YouTube which has yet to be monetized. They seem to be ignoring that. I just don't get it, Maria. I'm not going to say the analysts are wrong, the market is wrong, I just don't get this particular equation. And if I was left to guess, I'd say that Google bounces back fairly quickly to not necessarily its old high which is 12 percent high than where it is now, but certainly bounces back from this downturn that it's going to take first thing this morning. What do you think? What do you think?

BARTIROMO: Well, it was a big number in terms of what they're spending. You know how they have all of these other businesses that they want to --

VARNEY: Sure.

BARTIROMO: -- that they want to diversify. But 90 percent of the business is still, what, search and advertising, right?

VARNEY: Isn't this what they're supposed to do? I mean, aren't you supposed to plow back your profits in to expansion, new businesses, and (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: That's true, yes. You would think analysts like that.

VARNEY: Yes, you would have thought. But this time, no. I'm sorry, I don't get it. But I'm not nasty about analysts or that or expectations. I just don't get it.

BARTIROMO: All right. Well, I know you'll have more on it. And plus, you're going to preview Disney. That's after the close tonight.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in about 10 minutes, Stu. Thanks so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

But first, the economy under President Trump. The President dining with Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell last night at the White House. It was Powell's birthday. Then saddle up, I'm speaking with the owner of one special horse named, you guessed it, Maria Bartiromo. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: We are less than an hour away from the opening bell this morning. We are expecting a gain at the start of trading about 100 points. Investors are watching earnings. But what also is important is what President Trump will say at tonight's State of the Union Address.

Joining us right now is Wayne Wicker, he is Vantage Point Investment Advisors' Chief Investment Officer. Wayne, it's good to see you this morning. Does the State of the Union matter to investors? What do you want to see in order to move markets tomorrow -- tonight?

WAYNE WICKER, CIO, VANTAGE POINT INVESTMENT ADVISORS: Maria, I think that this is the perfect time for President Trump to come out and talk to the nation. He's really standing on solid footing economically. You've seen jobless claims coming in really strong, you see these earnings are coming in well. I think that investors are really going to be focused on a level of optimism going forward in his words this evening, to propel markets higher.

BELL: Wayne, Lindsey Bell here. What's your read on the meeting last night, the dinner last night between Jerome Powell and President Trump and Steve Mnuchin and Richard Clarida? What do you think markets should take from that? Do you think that, you know, the Fed still remains independent. What's the underlying thing to read?

WICKER: Well, Lindsey, I think that we saw the big pivot at the beginning of this year, when we moved away from auto escalation to more of a data dependency. I think what we saw last night was a little bit more of the same thing, where the Fed is trying to be -- quite frankly, a little bit more benign in their approach, and I think the combination of what Fed Powell is talking about as well as some of these meetings that he had with the administration, solidified that in investors' minds these days.

BELL: What are you pricing in for rate hikes this year?

WICKER: Well, I would say that the market probably has it right, that you don't see any inflation right now, and it's modest growth in the United States, and really not that great a growth outside the United States. So, the market is suggesting maybe one hike later on this year. I don't disagree with that.

BARTIROMO: So, you would buy stocks here?

WICKER: I would absolutely buy stocks in this market. You've seen some really strong earnings growths for the first half of earnings reporting season here. I see that despite the fact that we had this V-shaped recovery which history would say, you may have some retracement at some point in the next few months. I think the longer-term outlook is very strong for equities today.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Wayne, great to have you weigh in. Thank you.

WICKER: Uh-huh.

BARTIROMO: Wayne Wicker joining us there. Up next, the owner of Maria Bartiromo, the horse. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, a winning combination, champions are crowned at Rodeo Rapid City in South Dakota this past weekend. One horse went 87 points for saddle bronc riding, and the name of that horse -- Maria Bartiromo. Joining us right now by the telephone is the owner of Maria Bartiromo the horse, Matt Burch. Matt, thank you so much for being here.

MATT BURCH, OWNER OF MARIA BARTIROMO THE HORSE (via telephone): Thank you for having us.

BARTIROMO: Why did you name your horse Maria Bartiromo?

BURCH: Well, my dad is the one that started this. We're big time Fox News watchers. And he was sitting there one day and he normally writes horses' names down on paper that he wants us to name, me and my brother, and he told us that he wanted us to find one horse and wanted to name it after you because you're an intelligent person, very classy, so he told us to make sure we picked it on a good one, so that age of colts we start them at 5 years old. And for about four or five trips, we could tell that this mare right here was the most talented, classy, intelligent one of the bunch.

MCDOWELL: Hey, Matt --

BURCH: And obviously, you can see she's very pretty. So, I think (INAUDIBLE) you know, big white mane on her.

BARTIROMO: She's gorgeous.

MCDOWELL: I have to (INAUDIBLE)

BURCH: After about five trips, my brother said there's our horse. So, we put your name on it and come to find out, she is our number one horse of that colt crop, and probably one of the best ones we're hauling down the road right now.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

MCDOWELL: Hey, Matt, did your daddy know that there was actually another horse, a racehorse that was also named after Maria Bartiromo at one point?

BURCH: Well, I've seen that before, yes. And I'm sure my dad did -- probably had seen that before, but you know, from the racehorse business to where we go is the (INAUDIBLE) horse deal, two totally different kind of horses. So, my dad is a very intelligent man, I'm sure he probably knew that.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I love -- I am so honored and she performed how often, Maria Bartiromo? Yes.

BURCH: Oh, that mare, well, she'll go about 20 trips all-year long. She goes to all of the biggest rodeos we go to. She's been to Houston, Texas, Clovis, California, (INAUDIBLE) Idaho, San Antonio, Texas, Denver, Colorado, Rapid City, obviously. Las Vegas, Nevada, to the (INAUDIBLE) NFR.

BARTIROMO: That is great. Listen, we're going to keep checking on her. We so appreciate it. And I appreciate it. I'm so honored, Matt, thank you very much. All the best to you and your father.

BURCH: Well, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Matt Burch --

BURCH: OK. (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: -- joining us.

MCDOWELL: We got to get you to a Rodeo. We got to go to the NFR in December. That is rad.

BARTIROMO: Let's do that. All right. Have a great day, everybody. Stuart Varney, take it away with "VARNEY & COMPANY."

END

urn:contentItem:5RB7-24C1-F03R-N0RS-00000-00Supercharged Wearables Are On The Horizon2018-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:28ZLexisNexisSupercharged Wearables Are On The HorizonAnne Zieger

Jan 03, 2018( EMRThoughts.com: http://www.emrthoughts.com Delivered by Newstex) Over the last several years, the healthcare industry has been engaged in a rollicking debate over the value of patient-generated health data. Critics say that it's too soon to decide whether such tools can really add value to medical care, while fans suggest it's high time to make use of this information.

That's all fine, but to me, this discussion no longer matters. We are past the question of whether consumer wearables data helps clinicians, which, in their current state, are under-regulated and underpowered. We're moving on to profoundly more-capable devices that will make the current generation look like toys. Today, tech giants are working on next-generation devices which will perform more sophisticated tracking and solve more targeted problems. Clinicians, take note of the following news items, which come from[1] The New York Times: Amazon recently invested in Grail, a cancer-detection start-up which raised more than $900 million Apple acquired Beddit, which makes sleep-tracking technology Alphabet acquired Senosis Health, which develops apps that use smartphone sensors to monitor health signals And the action isn't limited to acquisitions — tech giants are also getting serious about creating their own products internally. For example, Alphabet's research unit, Verily Life Sciences, is developing new tools to collect and analyze health data. Recently, it introduced a health research device, the Verily Study Watch, which has sensors that can collect data on heart rate, gait and skin temperature. That might not be so exciting on its own, but the associated research program is intriguing. Verily is using the watch to conduct a study called Project Baseline. The study will follow about 10,000 volunteers, who will also be asked to use sleep sensors at night, and also agreed to blood, genetic and mental health tests. Verily will use data analytics and machine learning to gather a more-detailed picture of how cancer progresses. I could go on, but I'm sure you get the point. We are not looking at your father's wearables anymore — we're looking at devices that can change how disease is detected and perhaps even treated dramatically. Sure, the Fitbits of the world aren't likely to go away, and some organizations will remain interested in integrating such data into the big data stores. But given what the tech giants are doing, the first generation of plain-vanilla devices will soon end up in the junk heap of medical history. [ 1]: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/26/technology/big-tech-health-care.html

urn:contentItem:5RB3-R3X1-JCMN-Y08K-00000-00Supercharged Wearables Are On The Horizon2018-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:28ZLexisNexisSupercharged Wearables Are On The HorizonAnne Zieger

Jan 03, 2018( EMRandEHR.com: http://www.emrandehr.com Delivered by Newstex) Over the last several years, the healthcare industry has been engaged in a rollicking debate over the value of patient-generated health data. Critics say that it's too soon to decide whether such tools can really add value to medical care, while fans suggest it's high time to make use of this information.

That's all fine, but to me, this discussion no longer matters. We are past the question of whether consumer wearables data helps clinicians, which, in their current state, are under-regulated and underpowered. We're moving on to profoundly more-capable devices that will make the current generation look like toys. Today, tech giants are working on next-generation devices which will perform more sophisticated tracking and solve more targeted problems. Clinicians, take note of the following news items, which come from[1] The New York Times: Amazon recently invested in Grail, a cancer-detection start-up which raised more than $900 million Apple acquired Beddit, which makes sleep-tracking technology Alphabet acquired Senosis Health, which develops apps that use smartphone sensors to monitor health signals And the action isn't limited to acquisitions — tech giants are also getting serious about creating their own products internally. For example, Alphabet's research unit, Verily Life Sciences, is developing new tools to collect and analyze health data. Recently, it introduced a health research device, the Verily Study Watch, which has sensors that can collect data on heart rate, gait and skin temperature. That might not be so exciting on its own, but the associated research program is intriguing. Verily is using the watch to conduct a study called Project Baseline. The study will follow about 10,000 volunteers, who will also be asked to use sleep sensors at night, and also agreed to blood, genetic and mental health tests. Verily will use data analytics and machine learning to gather a more-detailed picture of how cancer progresses. I could go on, but I'm sure you get the point. We are not looking at your father's wearables anymore — we're looking at devices that can change how disease is detected and perhaps even treated dramatically. Sure, the Fitbits of the world aren't likely to go away, and some organizations will remain interested in integrating such data into the big data stores. But given what the tech giants are doing, the first generation of plain-vanilla devices will soon end up in the junk heap of medical history. [ 1]: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/26/technology/big-tech-health-care.html

urn:contentItem:5Y7T-6MT1-JCMN-Y504-00000-00Superficial Intelligence vs. Artificial Intelligence2020-02-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:28ZLexisNexisSuperficial Intelligence vs. Artificial IntelligenceShelly Palmer

Feb 19, 2020( Shelly Palmer Digital Living: http://www.shellypalmer.com/category/blog/ Delivered by Newstex) According to Venture Beat[1], 'The European Union is set to release new regulations for artificial intelligence that are expected to focus on transparency and oversight as the region seeks to differentiate its approach from those of the United States and China.' I am looking forward to seeing the final form of these new regulations. But, if GDPR is any indication of how EU regulators think, it will not accomplish the stated goal of making the EU AI competitive. That said, I am a fan of the notion that it is not inevitable that big tech and nation-states have the exclusive rights to turn our data into action. This may be the most important subject for the next 100 years; that which controls the data wins! It's that simple, which means deciding what 'that' is really, really matters. Author's note:This is not a sponsored post. I am the author of this article and it expresses my own opinions. I am not, nor is my company, receiving compensation for it. The post Superficial Intelligence vs. Artificial Intelligence[2] originally appeared here on Shelly Palmer[3] [ 1]:

https://venturebeat.com/2020/02/17/eus-new-ai-rules-will-focus-on-ethics-and-transparency/ [ 2]:   https://www.shellypalmer.com/2020/02/superficial-intelligence-vs-artificial-intelligence/ [ 3]:   https://www.shellypalmer.com
