The high court takes up the issue of health care. We will break doubt the Supreme Court's possible ruling and what it means for your health.

COSTELLO: Just about 30 minutes past the hour. Checking our top stories now.

The countdown under way for tomorrow's Supreme Court decision on Obama care. The justices looking at several aspects of health care reform laws, including the requirement that nearly everyone buy health insurance. The court will decide if that part of the law is constitutional.

In Colorado, at least ten wildfires are burning, including this one north of Colorado Springs. It's not known how many homes have been lost to the Waldo Canyon fire, but it has forced the evacuation of at least 32,000 people. Flames are now getting close to the Air Force Academy campus.

Across much of Florida, the rains have stopped, but the floodwaters aren't going anywhere. Debby is now a tropical depression, but only after dumping nearly two feet of rain in some areas. Some towns still knee deep in water.

As we've been telling you, tomorrow is a critical day for both the future of health care and for the Obama administration. As the Supreme Court is set to issue a history-making decision on the President's health care law. The justices could rule in a number of ways, including upholding the entire law or striking it down.

The court could also rule that parts but not all of the law violate the Constitution. Moments ago, Republican House Speaker John Boehner had this to say about the Supreme Court's ruling and what might happen after it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JOHN BOEHNER (R-OH), HOUSE SPEAKER: We made it pretty clear, and I'll make it clear one more time. If -- if the court does not strike down the entire law, the House will move to repeal what's left of it. Obama care is driving up the cost of health care and making it harder for small businesses to hire new workers.

Our focus has been the economy and it will continue to be the economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

COSTELLO: The impact of the Supreme Court's ruling will reach far beyond Washington.

Here to talk about what's on the line for you is our chief medical correspondent, Dr. Sanjay Gupta. He's also a practicing neurosurgeon at a public hospital in Atlanta. And he worked in the White House during the Clinton administration. Good morning, Sanjay.

DR. SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CHIEF MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Carol.

COSTELLO: So if the entire law is thrown out, will anyone notice? Because most of it hasn't been -- you know, won't go into effect until 2014.

GUPTA: No, it's a good point. I think the immediate impact will be probably pretty minimal. And -- and by the way, a lot of the big insurance companies, we've been talking to some of them to sort of get an idea of what they would do under the different scenarios that you just presented. There's a chance that a lot of the insurance companies may say, look, the entire law was not implemented but what's been implemented so far we're going to keep. Some of the health insurance companies may just decide to do that on their own, but they don't have to. It's not going to be the law, obviously, if this is -- if this is overturned.

So, you know, it's a little bit of a -- of a question mark right now, Carol.

COSTELLO: Oh, so many question marks. There is a chance the Supreme Court could throw out the individual mandate, you know, the requirement that almost all of us buy health insurance? And also throw out the ban of pre-existing conditions so insurance companies wouldn't be forced to accept everybody.

So if that scenario happens what key provisions would be left?

GUPTA: Well, that's a good question. And that is a -- that is a quite a likely scenario, the one that you just described, if they throw out the mandate, then the -- the -- this -- this ban on discriminating for -- for pre-existing conditions may go out with it as well.

But keep in mind, Carol -- and there's some 450 provisions to this bill. So there's lots of other things, potentially. Let me tick off a few of them that I think are quite important in terms of what might remain. And again this is based on some of our discussions, our reporting with the insurance companies. If you have insurance and you become sick, you can't be dropped. Right now, you could be dropped by your insurance company. No lifetime limits. Carol I tell you as a doctor that's a big one, because when people get sick, they can get to that lifetime limit very quickly.

Co-pays on preventative care, this is something that's been discussed a lot but the idea that people should be getting preventative care but they don't just because of the co-pays or additional costs.

And then the employers having to provide insurance, Representative Boehner was just talking about that.

The last one is a big one. I hear about this so much from people, especially in that age range, who say, I've finished school, I've gotten out of school. And I can stay on my plans -- parents' plan until age 26. That could remain as well.

Also incidentally, Carol, it makes small businesses much more likely to hire people in that age range because they already have health insurance that those businesses don't have to provide that health insurance for them.

COSTELLO: Ok so here's a question, we all do a good job of blaming the government or hospitals or insurance companies for the high cost of health care. What do Americans think? Are there any polls out there that show that?

GUPTA: In terms of what they think about this plan, you're saying?

COSTELLO: On who's to blame for the high cost of health insurance, health care costs, I should say?

GUPTA: Well, you know I mean, I think in part, we're to blame, meaning the citizens of the country. You know, I'll preface by saying, look, if you look across the world, Carol, no one does a terrific job at controlling health care costs. I mean, all countries, regardless of the types of insurance plans they have, health care costs have been going up.

But clearly, I think to your point, in the United States, it's -- it's been really out of sorts. I think in part, you know, consumers, if you look at us as a whole, we're very overweight or obese, for example. Close to three quarters of adults, 68 percent roughly are either overweight or obese. One in five people smoke. You know and that's -- that's -- these are -- these are both things that can lead to increased health care costs, just personal responsibility.

But let me make a larger point, and I think an important one, Carol. And that is that health assurance alone, health insurance alone does not lead to good health. You and I both know plenty of people who have terrific health care insurance but aren't in terrific health. And part of it is because they don't do a lot of things that we talk about. They don't go see their doctor, they don't get the preventive services despite the fact they have very good health insurance. So this is part of the equation.

Take a look, only half of Americans got preventative care services prior to 2010.

COSTELLO: And you know I never -- I'm one of them. I never do that because I'm in such great health and I'm like oh I don't want to take the time. But you're right.

GUPTA: Yes, well you know and this is part of it, you know 85 percent of the country has health insurance. That's the other side of this equation. But a significant percentage of them do not see their doctors. Do not take adequately good care of themselves; do not get those preventive services so there is a second beat to this story, Carol, which we're going to keep doing.

COSTELLO: Dr. Sanjay Gupta, thanks so much.

GUPTA: You got it, Carol.

COSTELLO: As we wait to see how the U.S. Supreme Court will rule on the health care law backed by President Obama. Mississippi is one of the 26 states fighting it. Even so, Mississippi is moving ahead with another provision of Obama care. That is, building an online insurance exchange.

Joining me now is the state's insurance commissioner Mike Chaney. Welcome, welcome Mr. Chaney.

MIKE CHANEY, COMMISSIONER, MISSISSIPPI INSURANCE: Thank you Carol, good morning to you.

COSTELLO: Good morning, first of all, explain what these exchanges are for our viewers?

CHANEY: Well, essentially an exchange is a market place for an individual or small employee use about health insurance for their employees or themselves individually. Mississippi has looked at exchanges for the last four years, actually since Massachusetts passed their exchange. And it came out at the Heritage Foundation.

You know an exchange is not a Democrat or Republican idea. It's a universal idea. It's way to market insurance to reduce the costs and give our consumer's options.

(CROSSTALK)

COSTELLO: Yes, I was just going to ask you, Mike, how exactly does this make insurance cheaper for those who can't afford health care?

CHANEY: It gives -- it gives the consumer a lot of choices, Carol that they do not have today. There's no guarantee that that insurance will be cheaper on an exchange. It's a marketplace, it's a paradigm shift from what we've been accustomed to in the past. Exchanges where -- as I said a universal idea, it's something that came about before the Affordable Care Act was actually passed. COSTELLO: So are you accepting federal money out of the Obama care provisions to set up these exchanges in Mississippi?

CHANEY: We're taking the federal money to set up exchanges in Mississippi. Our goal is to have an exchange that will comply to federal law, so if the court upholds the Affordable Care Act. If the court does not uphold the Affordable Care Act, our goal then is to have an exchange that will be a pre-market based exchange to be able to market different types of insurance, health insurance products on the marketplace for consumers, and for our small employers.

And to that end we already have several companies lined up to market products on the exchange. We have a portal up and running it's www.onemississippi.com. It's o-n-e -- you spell out m-i-s-s-i-s-s-i- p-p-i.com. So you can got look at it if you want to consumers can, too.

COSTELLO: And then a final question, you're Republican, but you said that the exchanges are not a Democratic or Republican idea. But the whole health care law, Obama care as Republicans call it derisively, I might add.

In your opinion, is Obama care a good law or bad law? And what should the U.S. Supreme Court do since you're already implementing some of what's in Obama care?

CHANEY: Well, let me answer that two ways, Carol. One, I didn't have a vote on Obama care. Or as you all call it, I call it the Affordable Care Act which is the proper name. But if I had a vote, I would have voted against the law very simply. There are a lot of parts of that law that should not be included in statutory law. And I think that puts the court in a precarious situation of trying to rule on -- on constitutionality of individual mandates, our tier one on Medicare and Medicaid.

It presents a host of problems for the court to try to rule. Nobody knows what the court is going to do. I have no clue as to what they will do. If you look at the second mandate that that -- that General Washington put out when he conscripted people into the Army, the individual mandate that you would supply ammunition and -- and guns and all the military things that you needed, the courts could argue that's what we're doing here.

I don't know what's going to happen. I don't think anybody does except the justices themselves.

COSTELLO: But I expect you will be watching with great interest tomorrow.

CHANEY: I'll be watching big time because it affects us, we've taken -- we've taken over $20 million of federal money to set up our exchanges here in the state of Mississippi. We've been very upfront saying, we're going to take the money, set it up, without using state dollars if we can. We hope the exchange, and we believe the exchange can operate without any state money or federal money being involved if it's free market. And that's our goal. You know I had great support from Haley Barbour. Three years ago, I served in the legislature when Haley had his first term. So I understand his thought process. I've known Haley for as almost 50 years. So we -- we think alike. We believe in free market solutions to complex problems.

So that's -- that's our approach to this -- this problem. It's an insurance problem. It's ironic that I, as a commissioner and dealing with health care benefits when I'm usually a regulator. But I enjoy it. It's a challenge for us and I'm up for the challenge.

COSTELLO: You are. And thank you so much for being with us and explaining this to us.

CHANEY: Thank you Carol. Thank you.

COSTELLO: It's just so fascinating. Thank you, Mr. Chaney.

What gadgets can we expect from Google? Maybe a tablet? We'll have a live report from Google's Developers Conference. Yes, that's going on in San Francisco. And interesting things are coming out of it. We'll tell you.

COSTELLO: In just the last 30 minutes, Republican House Speaker John Boehner said the House will go forward with a contempt vote against Attorney General Eric Holder. Boehner claims Holder is withholding documents relating to the government's botched gun sting "Fast and Furious". Joe Johns was at the Speaker's news conference. He joins us from Capitol Hill to tell us what Mr. Boehner said. Hi, Joe.

JOE JOHNS, CNN CRIME AND JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Carol, as you know, generally, when you have things like this that come to a head they get negotiated out before you get to the final conclusion which would be in this case a vote for contempt on the floor of the House of Representatives.

There have been behind the scenes talking as recently as last night, but clearly, no solutions have been reached. The Speaker of the House just a little while ago talking in the basement of the United States Capitol, saying he does now still plan to proceed with that vote of contempt against Attorney General Holder. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JOHN BOEHNER (R-OH), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Brian Terry's family has a right to know what happened. The American people have a right to know what happened. And we're going to proceed.

We've given them ample opportunity to comply, even as late as yesterday. The White House sat down with some of our staff that outlined what they'd be willing to do. Unfortunately, they're not willing to show the American people the truth about what happened. It's an unfortunate -- it's an unfortunate place where we are. But our members raised their right hand and swear to uphold the constitution of the United States and the laws of the United States. We're going to do our job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JOHNS: Of course, the back story here is about the National Rifle Association, a very powerful lobby here in Washington, D.C. They are counting this vote, they tell me, which means there will be very likely be some Democrats who will very seriously consider voting against Attorney General in order to preserve their NRA rating.

I talked to the National Rifle Association just a little while ago. They tell me they have actually heard from some Democrats in NRA supporting districts, who say they will be voting against Attorney General Holder.

So why is the NRA doing this? Well, they say, they believe the "Fast and Furious" operation which is at the root of all of this actually was a part of a larger gun control strategy, if you will, which is something the NRA is very much against.

I asked Speaker Boehner if there was evidence of that. He said he never said that in the first place. So that's something that's sort of coming out of the oversight reform committee. We're asking around the hill, Carol, for the evidence of a larger gun control strategy in the "Fast and Furious" operation.

COSTELLO: Well, you know Joe, Democrats call it a conspiracy theory. And Republicans -- some Republicans say that that's why the government isn't turning over those doubts, because the Obama administration is secretly creating this gun control thing. And these documents will show that what's what "Fast and Furious" was really about.

JOHNS: Absolutely. And there's also some suggestion that the chairman of the oversight committee over on the house side Darrell Issa has actually said he has gotten ahold of an e-mail or two that seemed to point in that direction. And we'd like to see that e-mail ourselves.

COSTELLO: Yes, we would, wouldn't we? Joe Johns, you work on that.

JOHNS: Thanks, Carol.

COSTELLO: Thank you so much.

Big shift for Apple. Apple now changing its tune when it comes to how safe Apple computers are. As in viruses? Maybe Apple is not so immune after all.

COSTELLO: Apple now admitting it's not exactly immune to viruses these days. Alison Kosik is at the New York Stock Exchange. This is disturbing, Alison. ALISON KOSIK, CNN CORRESPONDENT: It's disturbing, but it's not really that surprising. I mean think about what Apple is like. When it announces a new product, it's not shy about it. It kinds of puffs up its feathers and makes its big new announcements. Here's what's curious. The company was pretty darned quiet about not being so ironclad with its security.

You know how a lot of people learned about this? Through a blog called Naked Security, that was first to notice this. So, if you actually go to Apple's Web site and you look on the "Why you love a Mac" page, the language used to be it doesn't get PC viruses. Well, guess what? It's changed. It now says "It's built to be safe."

What happened here is a big Trojan virus infected more than 500,000 MACs back in April. Now Apple has always bragged about how much safer its operating system is compared to Windows. But you know what; with more and more people buying MACs, the odds of getting a virus naturally go up. So Apple has to put its pride to the side.

Experts point out though regardless of whatever operating system you have Carol, you -- not you, but meaning the user -- are the biggest risks. You always have to keep your security programs up to date. And that all means don't download anything you don't -- like you know those attachments, don't just download anything that comes your way.

COSTELLO: I know. I learned my lesson the hard way. Alison Kosik, thank you so much.

KOSIK: Sure.

COSTELLO: What's coming up from Google? Will it enter the tablet market? We're about to find out with the tech giant kicking off its annual developers conference today. CNN's Dan Simon is front and center in San Francisco. Hi, Dan.

DAN SIMON, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Hi Carol. Well, we all remember when the titanic battle in technology was between Google and Microsoft. Well, today's battle is between -- I'm sorry, it was between Apple and Microsoft. Today's battle is between Google and Apple -- iPhone versus Android. Now we're looking at Google's I/O Conference, I/O stands for input and output. And you've got thousands of developers from all over the world coming to downtown San Francisco to see the latest Android products.

At this point, Carol, you really have to say it's advantage Google, right now, when it comes to Smartphone market share. Google now has about 62 percent of the global market share. So we'll see what Google has up its sleeve in about two hours from now -- Carol.

COSTELLO: What about that tablet?

SIMON: Well, it's interesting, you know, most of the tablets that have been released have been flops with the exception of Apple's iPad. So Google expected to introduce its own tablet today. We believe it's going to be about seven inches, smaller than the iPad, retailing for about $200. And this is really sort of to blunt what Microsoft came out with last week with its Surface and also Amazon's Kindle Fire.

We'll see how the tablet does. It should enter the market pretty soon. And of course, anytime Google unveils a product, it's a big deal. And this is their first tablet -- Carol.

COSTELLO: Can't wait to see it. Dan Simon reporting live from San Francisco.

What is an Olympic no-no? A woman in a bikini or a man in a Speedo? If you ask one Olympic swimmer, the answer is painfully clear.

COSTELLO: An update now on Karen Klein, the grandmotherly bus monitor who was tormented by a group of middle schoolers. After the video of that went viral, donations poured in and look at that. Karen Klein has met the man who helped raise more than $500,000 for her to take a vacation.

Max Sidorov came all the way from Toronto to Greece, New York. He said he never expected to raise so much money. His initial goal was just $5,000 and so far the total is over $660,000. Klein has said she may invest some of the money and also donate some of it.

Also, this morning, the Olympic rings are now on London's iconic Tower Bridge. It marks the final countdown to the opening ceremony just 30 days away. The rings are showing up all over London as the city prepares for the games which you better hurry if you want to go. The BBC is reporting 80 percent of the tickets have been sold.

Finally this hour, what's with Australia? Land of Wolverine Hugh Jackman, vicious dingos and naughty Olympians.

Take Olympic swimmer, Stephanie Rice. She tweeted a picture of herself in a swimsuit -- here it is. Australia is not happy. According to Yahoo! Sports this is a no-no, too skimpy, not dignified. Have Australians ever seen photos of Michael Phelps in a Speedo? Let's see that Speedo. Or America's newest sensation Ryan Lochte?

I'm sure Australian men bare most of their bodies too except of course when they're posing with a couple of pump-action shotguns. Australia wasn't happy with that, either, even though Nick Darcy and Kendrick Monk were at a shooting range. What could be worse? A naked Australian wielding weapons embedded in his hands?

That would have been so much better with the sound. Anyway, the lesson here -- I'll leave that to you.

And I'll say good afternoon, and thanks for joining me today. I'm Carol Costello.

CNN NEWSROOM with Kyra Phillips continues after a quick break.

urn:contentItem:5T9X-5T21-DY0W-42FG-00000-00Supreme Court Showdown; Florence's Fury; 10-year Treasury Yield Hits Fourth Month High; Trump Slams Sessions; Democratic Infighting; Pelosi in Peril; Smart Won't Live In Fear; Best And Worst U.S. Airports; Delta Raises Fees For Checked Bags; NYC Flood Rat Goes Viral; Vista Global Acquires XOJET2018-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:29ZLexisNexisSupreme Court Showdown; Florence's Fury; 10-year Treasury Yield Hits Fourth Month High; Trump Slams Sessions; Democratic Infighting; Pelosi in Peril; Smart Won't Live In Fear; Best And Worst U.S. Airports; Delta Raises Fees For Checked Bags; NYC Flood Rat Goes Viral; Vista Global Acquires XOJETLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Dagen McDowell, good morning to you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning ladies, good morning to everyone. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, September 20th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Supreme Court showdown, republicans warn that time is running out for nominee Brett Kavanaugh's accuser to testify. President Trump defending his pick for the high court and waiting to see what Christine Blasey-Ford's decision will be.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If she shows up and make a credible showing, that will be very interesting and we'll have to make a decision. But I can only say this, he is such an outstanding man, very hard for me to imagine that anything happened.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We have the very latest coming up. Futures are showing this reaction in the markets, we have gains across the board at the moment. A 29-point gain on the Dow Futures. This after a mix session on Wall Street yesterday. The Dow Jones almost 159 points, it is now less than one percent from its all-time high.

The S&P500 also closing higher, again, less than a quarter of a percent from its all-time closing high. The NASDAQ finishing lower on the day, it's roughly half a percent from its record. So that Dow record, it was hit earlier this year in January, we are watching for it today. Check the global market action.

In Europe, we have gains across the board, the biggest gainer there, the CAC Quarante in France, up six-tenths of one percent.

And in Asia overnight, markets little change there but we had green across the board except for the Shanghai dipping slightly.

Police under attack, officers on both sides of the country shot overnight, we have the latest on their conditions.

Alibaba backtracking, Jack Ma says his company's pledge to create one million jobs in America is off the table. He's blaming the trade dispute with China. The fallout ahead.

And say so long to the pizza rat, there is a new rodent going viral, the flood rat. Tough little cookie that one.

All that and so much more coming up this morning. Joining me, former State Department Spokesperson, Spokesman, Host of "BENSON & HARF" on Fox News Radio, Marie Harf. I was listening to it yesterday.

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO HOST: Woo.

MCDOWELL: Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner Mike Murphy. And Forbes Media Chairman, former Republican Presidential Candidate, the incomparable Steve Forbes. As I tweeted last night Steve, great of you to be here.

STEVE FORBES, MEDIA CHAIRMAN, FORBES: Good to be with you. Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Again --

FORBES: Great way to begin the day with that description.

MCDOWELL: Great way to begin the day with you three smarties here.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO & MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up this morning also, Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar is here. Former Republican Presidential Candidate Herman Cain. Vista Global Chairman and Founder Thomas Flor. You don't want to miss any of the guests coming up in the next three hours.

To our top story, Supreme Court showdown, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley setting a deadline of tomorrow at 10:00 a.m. for a response from Brett Kavanaugh's accuser amid a back and forth battle on whether or not she will testify on Monday.

Christine Blasey-Ford is alleging that Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her more than 30 -- about 35 years ago. Grassley also demanding an unredacted copy of a letter the Ford sent to the Committee's ranking democrats Senator Dianne Feinstein regarding the alleged incident dated July 30th.

President Trump eager to hear from Ford saying, "It would be 'unfortunate'" if she does not testify."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I would say this, I think he's an extraordinary man, I think he's a man of great intellect as I've been telling you, and he's had an unblemished record. This is a very tough thing for him and his family. And we want to get it over with, at the same time we want to give tremendous amounts of time. If she shows up, that would be wonderful, if she doesn't show up, that would be unfortunate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Steve, how do you think this plays out?

FORBES: I thought the president in that -- just that little clip you had handle it just right. She should take that opportunity to testify, let the Committee decide, let the American public decide instead of doing it through leaks or trying to do it through having setting conditions and things like that.

But the fact is that she's equivocating, it's not a good thing for the dems but she should just testify --

MCDOWELL: What do you --

FORBES: -- and let -- and let the Committee decide.

MCDOWELL: What do you make of how Senator Chuck Grassley has handled this? Because the republicans on the Committee led by Grassley, they have really tried to make -- they -- they've said, "We will -- we will listen to Ford at a time and place convenient to her." They've even offered to send individuals from the Committee out to wherever she wants to meet them.

That it isn't that -- and they were -- and they pushback on this, Grassley did a couple of days ago, you have to sit next to Brett Kavanaugh and face -- and this accuser has to face this man head-on. That's not what they're talking about. They've really tried their best to make -- get her to talk to them.

FORBES: Yes. They know that obviously these are very, very serious allegations and therefore it's got to be treated with utmost seriousness and so they're going out of their way.

Create an environment where she can talk about it if she wishes to do so, make the accuser in public if she wishes to do so, half the members of the Committee will be very sympathetic and so she'll have support there.

So they're doing everything to make it -- put it out in the public, make your statement, let the Committee and the public decide. And so I think Senator Grassley has been such a vivid contrast to some other members of that Committee that most Americans are going to say, she made an accusation, go out, do it in public and let's see what happens next. The president, I thought that statement was just right.

MCDOWELL: He might -- I -- we have been watching Senator Hirono from Hawaii and she has certainly gone overboard screaming, literally yelling about all men need to shut up and step up. Even I think she used an exploitive when she was talking to "ABC" yesterday.

So we understand she's upset but that doesn't really solve this issue for the republicans and for the democrats.

HARF: Right. The goal should be to get whatever truth you can get after 35 years for the Senate to consider this new allegation as part of its advice and consent on this nominee. She should -- I think that Dr. Ford should testify in some way whether it's publicly or privately.

But the political reality, Dagen, I think is that if there are no other accusations, if there are no people out there saying this is a pattern, if there are no other women just from a political standpoint, I think she will get to give her side of the story, Judge Kavanaugh will also get to and my sense is, as long as that just basically turns into a he said she said in front of the Committee, Brett Kavanaugh will be confirmed. That's my political sense right now.

MCDOWELL: Will you admit that this demand that -- and this is not just from the accuser and her lawyers, this is kind of a narrative from the democrats on the Committee and even outside of the Committee that the FBI must investigate this.

The FBI is not -- is -- they're not responsible for a -- basically investigating and being political judges, making determinations as they would in a criminal case. They're responsible as they were in the Anita Hill case initially when the accusations was still private.

They interviewed the parties involved and in a couple of days -- in just a few days and then handed that off to the Committee and then once those allegations about Clarence Thomas became public, it was handled b the Committee, not the FBI.

HARF: So I think two things, I do think there are other people that she alleged that were involved that should actually also testify before the Committee. Mark Judge, this other man that she alleges was part of the situation, he spoken publicly, they want the truth, he should also testify before the Committee.

MCDOWELL: He issued a statement. Uh-hmm.

HARF: But I think the F -- what the FBI can do, they issue background checks. And whenever you have a clearance or some sort of background check, if new information comes to light, they look at it, they evaluate it and they see whether it has bearing on that person's background check.

I think the FBI could do that. And I don't think that would be unreasonable. If we want to get the truth and we want to check every box to make sure we're taking this seriously, I don't know why that can't be done at the same time. The Committee is moving forward, it seems reasonable to me.

MURPHY: Yes. It's very -- a very serious allegation obviously. But it's unfortunate that it became a political grandstanding event, that it was held back that this information wasn't brought to the public until this time right before a vote was due to come.

So I think that in it of itself just takes down the seriousness of it a little bit. If this -- if there's an allegation of sexual assault that you're holding on to, you should bring that out, you shouldn't wait until a final minute to kind of gain some political points for it I think

MCDOWELL: Well the reason that so many people on the right and republicans are upset Steve is because it's very obvious based on the democrats and Senator Feinstein sitting on this allegation for some weeks, it's a political ambush.

It's political chicanery. The goal is to definitely delay the -- this vote until after the midterm elections and I just -- that's the big question is, how does this -- how does this impact the democrats? How does it impact the republicans between now and when people go to vote?

FORBES: Well, that's why she should testify, Dr. Ford should testify on Monday so people can see it and you have the accuser, you have the defender and make their statements. But politically, I think the democrats sort of know Kavanaugh, Judge Kavanaugh will probably be confirmed.

But what they're going to try to do is say, "You see, they're republicans, they're misogynist, they don't care about women, this is just one more incident, just suppress republican suburban turnout." And --

HARF: And the last time this happened with Anita Hill and with the next election, 1992, a record number f women came out to vote, it was the year of the women when a bunch of women got elected and one of the major driving factors in that election was the Anita Hill hearing. But just politically what you're saying Steve --

FORBES: And that's why -- and that's why the president --

HARF: This is a calculation.

FORBES: -- I think is so calm yesterday. From the beginning he said they're allegations, she should have every opportunity to bring them out there and have a fair hearing. Not the usual punch back, they all know they got to be very careful with this, so give her every opportunity to get her story out that's why it's essential.

And I think that Senator Grassley is right, give her the opportunity on Monday in a -- in a proper setting, so it's not adversarial as they sometimes try to do and have it out there. And if she does not take that opportunity, that speaks wrong (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: Chuck Grassley has said public or private we will send individuals to you in California if that's what it takes for people on this Committee to talk to you. I just think a lot of women see this big blue bumper sticker out the midterms, "Men are liars."

That commanding the conversation are people like Senator Hirono but even Joy Behar who came out yesterday and said, "Oh, white man protecting a man" and she asserted that Kavanaugh is probably guilty and I -- that's what gets a lot of the attention in this country, not the kind of reasonable treatment of an accuser in a Supreme Court nominee but, again, the people who are yelling the loudest who have the biggest megaphone.

HARF: Yes. And I think a lot -- a lot will depend on how this hearing goes if it happens because there are a lot of women, suburban women, independents who will help decide this election that want to see if the republicans will treat her with respect, right?

And so far we have -- you know, everything, it's been better than the Anita Hill situation but that's not a high bar. So, I think that we will be watching very closely to see how this place out. And some -- there have been some hysterical comments on the republican side as well. So we will - - these next few days are going to be weird.

MCDOWELL: No yelling, no hysteria here.

HARF: Exactly. We're all calm.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And we take you back down South, Florence's fallout, President Trump making stops in North and South Carolina touring areas most affected by this horrific storm. This comes as we're learning that the flooding cleanup could last years. Griff Jenkins, FOX News Correspondent is live in Fayetteville, North Carolina with more. Good morning Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Dagen. Yes. Fayetteville would like to start getting back on its feet but it could be days or weeks because of the water.

The main bridge downtown behind me closed for structural integrity and that's because the Cape Fear River, pressed at a record 61.5 feet yesterday. You look at this drone video shot by Councilman Jim Arp, the Fayetteville City Council, it's just amazing the flooding going on there.

We had a chance to speak with the mayor here, Mitch Colevin for a while yesterday and he told us what he hopes the president and the administration will do in terms of getting them resources, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MITCH COLEVIN (D), FAYETTEVILLE CITY MAYOR: If I ever get an opportunity to speak to the administration and the people in the White House, I want to tell him that that is something that I'm very concerned with as the small businesses getting back up and running. Two years ago when we have Matthew, you know, FEMA was here in -- very quickly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: Fayetteville was spared a little bit of beating perhaps because 30 miles south, the rain Dagen, even double, 36 inches there, about 15 here in the city. But as President Trump toured areas, he didn't come here but as he toured all the areas he assured everyone in the storm he had their backs in mayors just like Mayor Colevin, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're getting all teed up for a lot of money to come down to the area, they're going to need it and we have it and we will be supplying it. And there will be nothing left undone, you'll have everything you need.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: In the flooding south of here also still a major issue, Highway 95 closer to Lumberton still shutdown in some areas, so it is indeed going to be days if not weeks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Griff, we appreciate you being there very much. Griff Jenkins because I -- you were in that storm and you've -- and you've stayed to cover the aftermath because it matters. Thank you so much Griff.

We'll be speaking with Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar on the health effects following these catastrophic floods at 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time.

Comng up, Alibaba backtracking, why Jack Ma is now walking back his promise to create one million jobs in the U.S.

Plus, one soggy commute, the New York City flood rat, he's taking (INAUDIBLE) the internet by storm this morning, more of this video for you straight ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Four police officers on both sides of this country shot in the line of duty. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Dagen, good morning. All right. To Los Angeles, two deputies were in the hospital this morning while following a chase and a shootout there. The suspects opened fire as the deputies were responding to a call about a man flashing a gun near park.

Both deputies shot in the upper body, they're in stable condition luckily, one suspect was killed, two others are in custody. Then to Maryland, two officers were shot while serving a drug-related search warrant. The unidentified cops flown to a trauma center after being hit in the hand and shoulder. They are expected to survive, the suspect is in jail. Thirty seven police officers have been shot and killed in the line of duty so far this year.

Well, as the trade fight between Washington and Beijing intensifies, Alibaba Founder and Chairman Jack Ma is now walking back his 2017 promise to create one million jobs in United States.

Ma says, "This promise was on the basis of friendly China-U.S. cooperation and reasonable bilateral trade relations that the current situation is already destroyed that basis. Earlier this week Ma said the trade war between the two countries could last for two decades.

Well, European Union Antitrust officials are reporting looking into Amazon's treatment of other merchants that sell products using its platform. Investigators want to know if Amazon is gaining a competitive advantage by using data from every transaction and from every merchant that sells on Amazon. There is no comment yet from Amazon on the investigation.

Meanwhile, Amazon is reportedly considering opening as many as 3,000 Amazon Go cashierless stores over the next three years. Currently, there are just three Amazon Go locations in Seattle, there's one in Chicago. Shoppers use their Amazon Go app and instead of dealing with a cashier, cameras and sensors keep track of what they buy. The accounts are automatically charged for whatever products they carry out.

Shares of Amazon are up 66 percent so far this year Dagen. And we should add they're going to be opening one up right here in New York City and some of us can't wait, we're very excited about that.

MCDOWELL: That is going to be a disaster.

CASONE: Oh yes. No, I'm excited about it.

MURPHY: Shoplifters are going to need to find a new job. You can't shoplift.

CASONE: I love it.

MURPHY: Anyone who --

HARF: They'll find a way.

MURPHY: -- wants to grab something can't do it anymore.

MCDOWELL: People -- there are going to be so many problems. The CVS across the street in my apartment has the -- you have to check yourself out. That is a nightmare.

MURPHY: It's a disaster.

MCDOWELL: They have -- that is a total disaster.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I don't know why Amazon thinks it can leapfrog even over that. They can't get those things to work. They have more people. If they just get rid of the machines and hire people to run the registers, it would be more helpful than having all these additional people to help the people who are self-checking out.

FORBES: It's still the same thing at the airport, they always have to have somebody there by the machine because it often doesn't work. But this is just rudimentary, eventually they'll get that technology right.

MURPHY: They will. They're getting it right. But also by using the technology, they get all your data. So if it was a cashier, they wouldn't know who you are, what you do but by using technology they can track you on what you're doing and what you have took.

HARF: I like real people. I like -- I'm old school, I like talking to people.

MURPHY: That is old school.

HARF: I know.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, in terms of data, that's why Amazon is really pushing this Whole Foods discount if you're a Prime member.

HARF: Oh, yes.

MCDOWELL: They -- every box you get from them, the actual tape on the box is shopping it. They have people in the stores, every cashier at Whole Foods is trying to push it because it wants your data.

MURPHY: And this is bad for obesity. It's one thing to be before a person and order five cheeseburgers, quite another one and just punch it in, no one's going to give you a bad look.

HARF: True. Great point.

MURPHY: Has this happen to you Steve? You want to tell us something?

FORBES: Well no. No, no, no.

MCDOWELL: By the way, it's pepperoni pizza day, so we are going to have some pepperoni pizza for you coming up.

CASONE: Woo-hoo.

MCDOWELL: Cheryl just went woo-hoo.

Coming up, also bumping up baggage fees, Delta joining United and JetBlue in raising its check bag fee, we'll tell you how much.

Plus, survey says the best and worst airports in the country according to travelers. We have the results ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: We are watching markets this morning, the Dow and S&P500 both less than one percent from their all-time highs and Futures are up across the board, 24-point gain on the Dow Futures right now.

And we're seeing it, there's been a selloff in Treasury's yield on the 10- year hovering above that three percent market, that's a four month high. Joining us now is Merrill Lynch and U.S. Trust Fixed Income Strategist, Matt Diczok.

Matt, what do you make of this about finally we're getting a little bit of a steepening of the yield curve where there's longer term interest rates have gone up. Is that a positive sign because people always talk about the inversion of it where shorter term rates are higher. Is a sign of economic weakness ahead?

MATT DICZOK, FIXED INCOME STRATEGIST, MERRILL LYNCH & U.S. ANTITRUST: Yes. Though it is a positive sign that long-term rates are moving up slightly, what that tells you is the market is basically onboard with what the Fed's policy is going to be for the next couple of meetings.

So the Fed said they're going to hike probably September, probably December. The Fed's forecasting three hikes next year, the market's a little bit less optimistic. The markets agreed with the Fed for the next couple of hikes. It was a little bit unclear next year. They had about one hike but now as the rates move up, the market is saying more and more they're comfortable with the Fed's policy as long as the 10-year rate because needs to move up in this range, we think we're in a good place right now.

MURPHY: I was surprised that the market overreacted the first time we came up near three percent yield on the 10-year, market sold off. But now I think the market understands that if the rates are rising for the reason reasons, it's OK.

So if we get three rate hikes next year, I think as long as its supported by an improving economy the market can continue to go quite a bit higher.

DICZOK: I think that's absolutely right. So as Dagen mentioned that flattening of the yield curve, right, two-tenth has come down to about 20 base points of so, that concern a lot investors. But we don't think it should be a concern for investors.

Now the point thing to look at is a three month to ten years or Fed funds the two-year spread. Right now it's about 90 basis points between the Fed funds or in a two-year rate. That tells you the market thinks that another two to three hikes from the Fed is OK, they're not concerned about it which would be concerned about would be an inversion, right?

MCDOWELL: Right.

DICZOK: Ten-year substantially below two-year rate for an extended period of time or two-year rates below the Fed funds rate. An inversion would tell you that the market thinks the Fed is too restricted in going to make a mistake, we're not close to that.

MCDOWELL: It's overshooting is going to whack the economy, even send the economy under a recession because people are buying those longer term bonds as a -- as protection if there's an economic downturn.

FORBES: Are you surprised that the --

MCDOWELL: I hope I got that right.

DICZOK: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Before 6:30 in the morning.

DICZOK: We don't -- we don't think -- in can be the kind of growth doesn't dive because of old age, right? It dies because of a Fed induced recession will try to get inflation down.

FORBES: Were you surprised by the reception of that $15 billion bond deal from Thompson Reuters, all these junk bonds, c-rate, CC, they gobbled -- markets gobbled it up, there's a huge appetite.

MCDOWELL: Zack Rosenberg, the Chief of the charity organization SBPUSA.org was on earlier and he said that he is sensing working with organizations like FEMA and HUD, Housing in Urban Development, that there is a real openness to true public private partnerships to make sure that A, gets to people quickly, that the rebuilding happens quickly.

Can you speak to that within Health and Human Services particularly given the fact that you came from the private sector.

AZAR: Oh sure. We -- it's vital that we be open to working with a private sector, to provide resources. That's one of the gray aspects of how we work here in America and the American governmental system that we never try to carry the burden alone from the government side but rather working in public/private partnership and taking advantage of the tremendous goodwill and charity of the American people who see catastrophic situation like this.

Their heart goes out to their fellow citizens and they want to be of assistance not just individual people but companies and organizations and we work to facilitate that, that's one of the important missions on in our public health service core.

MCDOWELL: I want to turn the opioid crisis, the Wall Street Journal has an article titled, "Opioid Crisis Emerges as Dominant Campaign Theme." The Department of Health and Human services granting $1 billion this week to fight this opioid crisis. Can you tell us where that money is going, how it's being spend?

AZAR: You bet. So the president's been providing decisive leadership here, highlighting and really making this a central issue or the country, the opioid epidemic that is devastating so many families, so many communities across every generation.

And just yesterday we released a $1 billion of A, the state and local government that help provide resources for prevention, for treatment, for recovery. This is going to help people get into medication-assisted treatment so they can break the cycle of addiction that's going to help states in controlling the flow of legal and illegal opioid. So this is vital relief around the country for all those suffering from this massive epidemic.

MCDOWELL: And I think that you'll agree with this Mr. Secretary, if a doctor tries to prescribe you opioids for the first time, you need to push back on that. It really starts with the individual in this country.

AZAR: It's really important that everybody have a very detailed discussion with their doctor about what they're being prescribed and why they're being prescribed. And you know, we're seeing really positive signs although we have a long way to go.

We've seen a reduction in the prescribing rates for legal opioids, we've seen a 264 percent increase since the president took office of Naloxone prescriptions which are those drugs, the overdose reversing drugs and we've seen from 2016 to 2017a 50 percent reduction in heroine use in this country.

So we've got a long way to go, we didn't get in this overnight but we're making progress all working together across our communities.

MCDOWELL: Mr. Secretary, Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar, thank you so much for being here.

AZAR: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, Amazon Go growing, Stuart Varney, he loves to talk about Amazon and he will do that. What's next for the e-commerce giant?

Plus, fighting the flood, more video of this little rodent taking on a torrential downpour inside a New York City subway. He's just like the rest of us who live here, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The battle for sky will be settled by auction this weekend. Connell McShane on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more. Hey Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, hello there Dagen. You know, it's interesting, this has been going on for close to two years, 21 months to be exact between the FOX Business Network parent company, 21st Century Fox and Comcast over who would end up with the British broadcasters giant.

But as regulators come out and said, "Yes, we're going to have an auction," kind of unusual. But that what they're going to do starting tomorrow ending on Saturday. Max three rounds of biding and we'll see who comes away with Sky. Market cap's $35 billion, so certainly the final number you think would be higher than that.

Now, before I go back to you, I also want to mention earnings today briefly, garden restaurants of Olive Garden chain and also a number of other restaurant chains, Longhorn Steak House, the Capital Grill and others, $0.10 better than expected this morning. In its most recent quarter, $1.34 versus $1.24, stocks been red hot. Looks like it will continue possibly up again an all-time high this morning.

It's a 40 plus percent over the last 52 weeks and I know, I think you guys have been following, speaking of Olive Garden Dagen, this story where they say they're going to have a huge reveal, mysterious countdown clock that emerge at Olive Garden, we know what it was about, it turns out Olive Garden is issuing 10 more of its annual pasta passes in some sort of a digital scavenger hunt. So strong sales and bad, so the world's a better place, I believe.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much Connell. Good to see you. Connell McShane at the New York Stock Exchange.

Amazon now considering opening as many as 3,000 cashierless, that's cashier free stores by 2021 according to a recent report. Joining us now, the Host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. You love talking about Amazon.

STEWART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I do. It's a brilliant company with extraordinary power and global reach and the guy who found it, it is now by far in a way the richest man in the world.

But what they're doing with these cashierless stores is really very advanced. As I understand it, now I've not been to one, they have experiment (INAUDIBLE) you walk in the store, you put your phone against some kind of scanner, walk around the store, takes stuff off the shelves which you want and walk out.

Everything's scanned and looked at electronically and you get the bill on your phone a little later. I don't think any other retailer has anything close to that and that may well be the way of the future. But Dagen, I draw your attention to a New York Times Op-Ed piece which reads as follows, "Why Jeff Bezos should push for nobody to get as rich as Jeff Bezos?"

The Times is behind the lefties move to reign big tech in especially Jeff Bezos and especially Amazon. They're under attack but what happens if the attacker succeed and reign in Amazon? Do we still get this kind of cashierless stores innovation? My answer is no.

We've got a problem with the concentration of wealth and power that the technology economy gives to us but we don't have an answer as to what to do with it.

MCDOWELL: I don't know, as long as -- as long as they keep innovating I don't see a problem with it. And I've got an entire lexicon of hand gestures that I would gladly teach to those tech billionaires if they would like to communicate with the New York Times in a nonverbal way.

VARNEY: I thought you're having a go at me there because I tend to use my hands a little do I not?

MCDOWELL: No, no, no. I do too. I think that we are from the same stock if you will.

VARNEY: Well the bottom line is that the attack is gathering steam and it's an attack on America's technology leaders and I don't know where it's going and I hope it fails.

MCDOWELL: Me too. Agreement. Stuart, thank you. We will see you in 11 minutes time, almost. Stuart & -- Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY." Brett Bear is coming up with Stuart, you don't want to miss Brett with Mr. Varney, 9:00 a.m. Monday through Friday. Three hours of Stuart straight ahead.

But for -- up here first, talk about a tech crunch, how this snack delivery services making a big splash in Silicon Valley, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Snacking made simple. The tech savvy delivery service called Snack Nation securing $12 million in Siri (INAUDIBLE) funding. The company founded on the idea of making healthy food more convenient than junkfood.

Joining us now the company's Co-Founder and CEO Sean Kelly. Sean, SnackNation, we attacked these boxes of SnackNation. So while we eat, please speak.

SEAN KELLY, CO-FOUNDER & CEO, SNACKNATION: Absolutely. You want to know a little bit about SnackNation?

MCDOWELL: Yes. Please sir.

KELLY: All right. We are the authority when it comes to discovering emerging an innovative snack food brands. And what we mean more specifically is that we're a tech enabled snack delivery service that delivers creations like these to thousands of companies and homes across the country.

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO HOST: Sean, you're telling me you can make something that taste like Cheetos but it's healthier for me, right?

KELLY: We don't necessarily make them but --

HARF: Or deliver it, not make.

KELLY: Absolutely, deliver. We're go and find the best emerging and innovative brands that's also better for you and clean delicious and bring them direct to people. So you can feel a little bit less bad of having the snacks you want.

HARF: Great.

MURPHY: Sean, good to see you. We are in full disclosure, Rosecliff Ventures are proud investors in SnackNation, in Sean's business. One thing we look forward Dagen when we're investing in a company's strong innovative leaders and Sean fits that bill, he's an awesome guy.

But what we love about this is they're delivering their snacks to you at your business. You know, we spend -- people are spending over eight hours a day at work and employers want to make sure that their employees have an opportunity to eat healthy while they're at work.

But one thing we love that I love to hear Sean speak about is the data that they're able to collect. When they send this box to you at work, what you're getting out of that Sean?

KELLY: Yes. In today's world it's so important to be able to continually iterate and innovate, right, especially if you're a big CPG company. So what we do is we go direct to the consumer, have a direct relationship with them at their most engage moments.

We collect consumer insights and data that we see back o the brands so they can better understand their customer and therefore improve their products. We also use all that data to determine what emerging brands are going to win tomorrow. So we have a little bit of a predictive analytics engine that gives us a leg up in this business.

MCDOWELL: Do you sell that -- the new -- do you take that new data and sell it?

KELLY: We do. We sell that actually back to brands and there's also different ways for us to work with industry leaders and big CPGs to deliver some of that information to them.

MCDOWELL: So are you growing -- so this is direct to individuals but also companies.

KELLY: Absolutely. So we started on the enterprise, the reason that we started, we don't really look at B2B and B2C as being different. It's all about just where the consumer is and today's business --

MCDOWELL: Business-to-business and business-to-consumer.

KELLY: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: That's from -- that's from the first.com bubble by the way.

KELLY: Yes. Yes. Well that's the -- we like -- we like afternoons. But for us it's like, "Why did you -- why did start at the office? It's because it's where the younger generation spends the most time.

HARF: Yes.

KELLY: And so for us there's not that much difference. But being able to collect these insights and (INAUDIBLE) will have a forward-looking view in terms of what's going to work and what's not is really important.

MCDOWELL: But I attack this box like I hadn't eaten for the last five weeks and there -- we're immediately plant-base options in these boxes, not --

KELLY: Well based on a plan that's not going away

MCDOWELL: It's not -- you know, I don't eat any animal products at all. But it is -- but it goes to also.

If you're dealing with corporate customers, if they're trying to make their entire workforce healthy and keep their healthcare cost down, that's a huge selling point.

FORBES: It's nice with chocolate chip cookies that are healthy and taste like chocolate chip cookie.

HARF: We also have pizza too.

MURPHY: To wash down the pizza.

KELLY: Absolutely. Lenny & Larry's pack of protein, Steve, those are good for the guns, good for the biceps.

FORBES: I'm getting ready for the Olympics.

MURPHY: Sean, real quick, is there -- so with this platform, is there anything after snacks that could next for SnackNation?

KELLY: Yes. So we're actually setting this up as a platform where we can really deliver any consumer products through this. So even though our focus is on snacks, is in -- by the way, snacks can be anything.

Seventy percent Americans say that anything can be a snack as long as it's in a convenient format. And so we're already starting to plug health and beauty items and other items to our consumer insights final.

MCDOWELL: Here's a -- here's a tip --

FORBES: Wow. Sounds like a mini Amazon.

MCDOWELL: Right.

KELLY: Well.

MCDOWELL: Here's a -- here's a tip, cauliflower and cassava flour crackers, there you go, they're delicious.

KELLY: Love -- I love casara -- cassava, it's great for anti-inflammatory.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. And Sean Kelly, great of you to be here. Please come back sir.

KELLY: Thanks so much, appreciate it.

MCDOWELL: Nice to see you.

KELLY: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: The flood rat next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: I'd say thank you and so long to Marie, Mike, and the fabulous Steve Forbes and we hope that flood rat's OK. Stuart, take it away. It's all yours my friend.

VARNEY: Yes. Good morning flood rat, Dagen and all, good morning everyone. We are really close to yet another record high for the Dow Industrials.

END

urn:contentItem:5SGV-F8B1-JB20-G1SK-00000-00Supreme Court Sides with Baker in Same-Sex Marriage Case; Apple Close to Becoming First Trillion-Dollar Company; Apple CEO Addresses Cell Phone Addiction; When TV Interviews Go Wrong, White House Downplays Expectations For Trump-Kim Summit; Giuliani Says His Comments Were For Hypothetical Situation; Trump Uninvites Super Bowl Winners From White House; Hawaii's Kilauea Volcano Has Destroyed at Least 117 Homes; Fuego Volcano Spews Deadly Clouds of Rocks, Gas and Ash; Saudi Arabia Issues First Driving Licenses to Women. Aired 1-2a ET2018-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:29ZLexisNexisCNN NEWSROOM1:00 AM ESTBrian Claypool, Bryan PatelNEWSInternational060518CN.V11Supreme Court Sides with Baker in Same-Sex Marriage Case; Apple Close to Becoming First Trillion-Dollar Company; Apple CEO Addresses Cell Phone Addiction; When TV Interviews Go Wrong, White House Downplays Expectations For Trump-Kim Summit; Giuliani Says His Comments Were For Hypothetical Situation; Trump Uninvites Super Bowl Winners From White House; Hawaii's Kilauea Volcano Has Destroyed at Least 117 Homes; Fuego Volcano Spews Deadly Clouds of Rocks, Gas and Ash; Saudi Arabia Issues First Driving Licenses to Women. Aired 1-2a ETJohn Vause, Jim Sciutto, Nic Robertson, Dave Jacobson, Patrick Oppmann, Ivan Cabrera, Laurie Segall, Jeanne Moos, John Thomas

White House downplays expectations from President Trump and Kim Jong-un talks; Giuliani says his comments were for hypothetical situation; Trump disinvites Super Bowl winners from White House, Philadelphia mayor slams Trump and defends the Eagles team; Hawaii's Kilauea volcano has destroyed at least 117 homes in the past month; Guatemala's Fuego volcano spews deadly clouds of rocks, gas and ash; Saudi Arabia issues first driving licenses to women; The U.S. Supreme Court has sided with a baker who refused to make a wedding cake for a same sex couple; Jack Phillips said it was against his religious beliefs and the couple accused him of violating anti-discrimination laws. Apple is on the verge of becoming the first trillion-dollar company as executives showed off the newest software upgrades on Monday Apple stock rose again pushing it closer to that milestone; Apple has developed Screen Time, a tech addiction tool aimed at helping us use our phones less and taking control back. Sometimes sitting down for an interview on live television could be a little nerve-wracking; some struggle to get their facts straight, others can't seem to get the names right, either.

[01:00] JOHN VAUSE, CNN ANCHOR: Welcome to CNN Newsroom, live from Los Angeles.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

Ahead this hour, expectations for the Trump-Kim summit dropping like a rock. So, how did we get from a very special moment for world peace to maybe it's just a meet and greet.

Plus, in Guatemala, they had no time to escape, dozens are killed after a volcano sends flows of lava and ash.

And, a decision in the legal battle in the U.S. over gay rights and legal freedoms ended on a baker who refused to make a wedding for a same sex couple.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

Hello, thank you for joining us everybody. I'm John Vause and this is Newsroom L.A.

It was barely a month ago when the U.S. President Donald Trump was proclaiming that he and North Korea's Kim Jong-un would try to make their upcoming summit a special moment for world peace.

Now, the White House seems to be trying to tamp down expectations. Even the president is saying the June 12th talks are going to be more of a get to know you situation.

Here's CNN's Jim Sciutto.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JIM SCIUTTO, CNN CORRESPONDENT: From the moment the president first suggested a summit with the North Korean leader, his goal had been ambitious and clear.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, U.S. PRESIDENT: If the meeting, when I'm there, is not fruitful, I will respectfully leave the meeting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SCIUTTO: This last week as he met in New York with his North Korea counterpart, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, reiterated the president's intentions.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: The complete verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SCIUTTO: No longer. Now the goal of the June 12th meeting in Singapore, just a meet and greet between President Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, this according to a source familiar with the discussions.

President Trump said the same publically on Friday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's really a get to know you kind of a situation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SCIUTTO: The plan, a source tells CNN, is to come to a broad agreement on North Korea dismantling its nuclear weapons program. Then negotiations would be handed over to Secretary Pompeo for discussions that could take years.

This, even as the U.S. still has received no assurances that North Korea will give up its nuclear weapons.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: I believe they are contemplating a path for where they can make a strategic shift, one that their country has not been prepared to make before. This will obviously be their decision.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SCIUTTO: With a downgraded agenda, there is concern growing in Congress that this summit is just for show.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ED MARKEY, U.S. SENATE DEMOCRAT: We're not going to extract concessions by made-for-TV diplomacy by the photo op that Kim wants, and I think that Trump wants as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SCIUTTO: Often before summits like this, there is a managing of expectations. In this case, really a massive downgrading of expectations, and not the outside world's, but the president's own expectations for this summit described as recently as last week.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SCIUTTO: Going from a summit where the goal is to have a major agreement, or getting close to a major agreement, to as the president said himself, "a meet and greet" to build the relationship.

Jim Sciutto, CNNWashington.

VAUSE: CNN's International Diplomatic Editor, Nic Robertson, joins us now live from Seoul in South Korea.

And, Nic, this is a summit light on details from everything to where the two leaders will actually meet when they get to Singapore, to you know the big stuff, like who will cover the costs of dismantling North Korea's nuclear program, which one study has put at $20 billion.

NIC ROBERTSON, CNN CORRESPONDENT: It seems they're going to have a lot of time to save up that $20 billion, doesn't it John? Because at the moment, as you said, the tangible detail just doesn't exist.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

It's all aspirational and at the moment, you know President Trump really does see himself, it appears, coming here really just to show Kim that he's willing and this is the man who he'll be doing business with, but let's not worry about the details, let's leave that to other people.

The timeframe here, even you know from what the state department is saying the (inaudible) of the president's first term of office at least. So, their creating an expectation here that this won't even be an issue come the next presidential elections. It really is long-term stuff, without articulating really even what they get to at the end of that, John.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VAUSE: And, the White House continues to insist, on Monday, that the maximum pressure campaign on North Korea through very tough international sanctions would continue. Even though the president said last week he wanted to avoid that kind of language, because everyone was getting on now.

But after the summit, how realistic is it to expect countries like China to stay on board?

ROBERTSON: Sure. Look, President Trump has shown his hand here. He was very bellicose, very loud, calling Kim Jong-un "little rocket man", "mad man", things like that last year. That had everyone worried to the point that they were prepared, because they though President Trump might do something like start a war and it was worth increasing sanctions.

[01:05] It convinced the Chinese leadership, it convinced many other people and Kim Jong-un among them. It worked, it got those tougher sanctions, it's gotten Kim to the table.

But now, President Trump has really shown that he just want to kind of go this alone with Kim Jong-un, a photo op really at the beginning, not clear what comes after that.

This has given China, Russia and others an opportunity to realize, okay, now we wait for our own best interests. We recognize that President Trump isn't - - the bluster is kind of empty, really, as far as they can see so far. So, let's follow our own national security interests and let's begin to sort of see what deals are out there.

So, for China, what would be the rationale for them to sign up back to tough sanctions? Now they know it might not be in their interests, because President Trump is looking for a deal in him own interest. Plus, there's a trade war, potentially looming, between the United States and China; the good will's gone, the cards are played.

So, President Trump may find it very hard to - - to - - to recalibrate and bring back a maximum pressure type situation.

VAUSE: It could end up being quite an expensive handshake between these two men at the end of the day, but I guess we'll see.

Nic, thank you.

Nic Robertson, live for us there in Seoul.

For more on this now, we're joined by our political commentator's Democratic strategist, Dave Jacobson, and Republican consultant, John Thomas.

So, as we get closer to the summit, the White House continues to sort of walk back expectations bigly.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

According to CNN's reporting, "Trump and his aides have suggested the most concrete product of the June 12th encounter could be a peace agreement formally ending the Korean War" - - which would not be a bad thing, "a far cry from the commitment to immediate denuclearization that the administration once insisted would be required for Trump to come to the table".

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VAUSE: So, John, is it possible that maybe the president just overhyped what was possible, what could be achieved at this summit and maybe he didn't understand the complexity of nuclear negotiation? JOHN THOMAS, REPUBLICAN CONSULTANT: I'm sure he didn't fully understand the complexity, but I wouldn't - - I think just saying that this is a photo op and a hand shake thing, I - - I - - I think that's underplaying what's going to come out of it.
